Family of a Canadian-Israeli woman, who was missing since Hamas militants ambushed a music festival in southern Isreal last Saturday, says she has died Twenty-two-year-old Shir Georgy went missing after the militant group attacked the music festival near Kibbutz Re'im last Saturday. Georgy's aunt, Michal Bouganim, says the family is a mess and heartbroken. Bouganim says the family is preparing to hold Georgy's funeral in Israel tonight. Georgy's aunt shared a video earlier this week where Georgy is seen sitting on the floor and taking shelter with other people. Georgy is the fourth Canadian to die in the Israel and Hamas conflict.

Este 14 de Octubre tendremos un eclipse anular de sol, que atravesar√° las tres Am√©ricas comenzando en el oeste de Estados Unidos, con su c√∫spide en Nicaragua y terminando en el este de Brasil.

Este eclipse se da en Luna Nueva de Libra.

Un eclipse es un portal de mucha energ√≠a: negativa y positiva. Nos fuerza a transformar y enfrentar cosas profundas que no vemos.

Al ser en Libra, habla de un comienzo de nuevas relaciones y proyectos, buscando el equilibrio entre dos partes en conflicto.

De 10 a 11 am de Arizona, nos encontraremos conectando bajo la sombra para impulsar que aquellos conflictos que hoy invaden al mundo encuentren armon√≠a entre las partes.

This October 14 we will have an annular eclipse of the sun, which will cross the three Americas starting in the west of the United States, with its peak in Nicaragua and ending in the east of Brazil.

This eclipse occurs on the New Moon of Libra.

An eclipse is a portal of a lot of energy: negative and positive. It forces us to transform and face deep things that we do not see.

Being in Libra, it speaks of the beginning of new relationships and projects, seeking balance between two parties in conflict.

From 10 to 11 am in Arizona, we will find ourselves connecting under the shade to encourage those conflicts that invade the world today to find harmony between the parties.

Do you join this intention?

Meditate with us this day, intending the BALANCE BETWEEN THE PARTIES.

Princess Mononoke Synonyms: Mononoke Hime Japanese: „ÇÇ„ÅÆ„ÅÆ„ÅëÂß´ Type: Movie Episode: 1 Status: Finished Airing Duration: 133 minutes Aired: Jul 12, 1997 Genre: Award Winning, Action, Adventure, Fantasy Season: Summer 1997 Studio: Studio Ghibli Synopsis When an Emishi village is attacked by a fierce demon boar, the young prince Ashitaka puts his life at stake to defend his tribe. With its dying breath, the beast curses the prince's arm, granting him demonic powers while gradually siphoning his life away. Instructed by the village elders to travel westward for a cure, Ashitaka arrives at Tatara, the Iron Town, where he finds himself embroiled in a fierce conflict: Lady Eboshi of Tatara, promoting constant deforestation, stands against Princess San and the sacred spirits of the forest, who are furious at the destruction brought by the humans. As the opposing forces of nature and mankind begin to clash in a desperate struggle for survival, Ashitaka attempts to seek harmony between the two, all the while battling the latent demon inside of him. Princess Mononoke is a tale depicting the connection of technology and nature, while showing the path to harmony that could be achieved by mutual acceptance. Ÿáÿ∞ÿß ŸÖÿß ŸÜÿµÿ™ ÿπŸÑŸäŸá ÿßŸÑŸÖÿØÿßÿÆŸÑÿ©: My name is Dr. Awad. I‚Äôm here on behalf of the Canadian Coalition of Palestinian Organizations. I would like to reiterate the points made by my colleagues in speaking about two issues, both foreign and domestic. At the domestic level, our Palestinian community has been seeing vastly increased levels of harassment and threats. We have had Palestinian doctors had their ratings on Rate Your Doctor slammed with comments about how they are terrorists and support Hamas. Palestinians who own grocery stores have had their windows smashed. I myself have received hate and threatening messages. My wife recieved this message - we will rape your daughter and come for your terrorist husband. Let‚Äôs be clear. I‚Äôm sorry to say this - but it is your language and all of the politicians that followed - that opened the door to this nonsense. By not acknowledging the nuances of this conflict from the beginning you gave a green light to educators, companies, and provincial and municipal governments to look one way. You empowered Canadians to look at anyone who mentioned palestine as an enemy. That is how we feel and these are the effects we are facing now. Kids being kicked out of school because of voicing their support, employees feeling unsafe because of their companies vocal stance with Israel, mosques feeling under attack -- the list goes on. If you do not fix this language with an apology and clear messaging about the rights of Palestinians we worry that these acts will continue against people here in Canada. for generations to come. Internationally, I will say this. I was just in Palestine. And in the West Bank which is 10 times better than Gaza And you know this Prime Minister. Nothing sanctions what happened to innocent civilians. The occupation, and the horrors of civilian deaths, illegal settlements, attacks on journalist, repeated attacks on Al Aqsa mosque, spitting on Christian worshippers have made the situation less likely to result in peace for all civilians. All who commit crimes should be held accountable. The Palestinians want peace. They do not want war ships. We aren‚Äôt looking for bullets. We are looking for prosperity for all, justice for all, and an end to the conflict. I will now break and turn it over to you for a response.

To the Cafeteria Catholics on this thread bashing the Bishop over a Priest, this piece should be good for you to digest. Copied. OWNERSHIP OF PROPERTIES BY PRIESTS IN THE CHURCH: UNRAVELLING THE ISSUES BETWEEN REV. FR. PROF . PAUL OBAYI AND THE CHURCH/BISHOP ONAH I took time to watch the over 30-minute live video of Fr. Paul Obayi, narrating his painful ordeal in the hands of the Bishop and the Catholic Diocese of Nsukka. My takeaway from the video is that the good priest, who happens to be a Professor of Communication, taught by the same professors who taught me, seems to be having slight identity crises. This is because I am sure that the highly educated priest professor knows the true and authentic history of the Catholic Church. He must as well have been taught and properly drills on the events that led to the policies and dogmas of the church during his years as a philosophy and theology student. Even if he didn't, I am sure that some postgraduate classes with Prof. Ike. S. Ndolo or Propaganda Formulation and management should have clarified him a bit more. This knowledge acquired over time should have been more than enough to equip Fr. Obayi to understand that a priest of the Catholic Church does not have the right to own properties. Historically, the reason why Priests are not allowed to get married is not to keep them holy, no, it is to preserve the properties of the church so that the wives and children of priests won't grow to start demanding the transfer of the Church's properties to them. Before the year 1123, priests, bishops, and popes were allowed to have wives and children. However, upon their death, their children would take the church to court and reclaim all their father's properties, including church buildings. It became rampant that Catholic priests built churches and parish houses with people's donations and contributions to the church, only for their wives and children to throw the worshippers away and reclaim the church as their father's properties. To solve this problem, Pope Benedict VIII in 1018, formally forbade priestly marriages. About a hundred years later, it was formally adopted by the First Lateran Council of 1123. It would take nearly 300 years before it was fully implemented as most priests kept wives and children unofficially as house helps, since keeping them unofficially guaranteed that they won't take away the properties of the church through Court Litigations. Therefore, it is surprising for a priest who is exposed to such or even greater depth of knowledge to say that he owns any property. According to the Canon and Vatican laws, a priest owns nothing. A priest is as good as a dead man. Anything bought in his name was automatically bought in the name of the Church. Even his clothes and shoes. That's why it is the duty of the church to house him, clothe him, feed him, and provide everything he needs. Also, the church does not approve of a lot of things he does in the Adoration as the church sees them as superstitious acts and the preachings that when you throw powder, you may get favours, all sound heretic to the church. When I was president of the St. Theresa's Cathedral Parish Blockrosary Crusade, I took it upon myself to understand the faith I profess. So, I read about three different accounts of the history of the Catholic Church, some of which their authors include Alan Shrek and Rev. J. Dacruz. I understood in clear terms what the church was all about. So that in 2019/2020 when my understanding of the person and being of God began to conflict with the teachings of the Catholic Church, I voluntarily withdrew from being a practicing Christian, and only identify as a Christian for political reasons. Therefore, Fr. Obayi, whom I believe in all sincerity is more knowledgeable than me, should renounce priesthood peacefully if he has the intention of owning properties that are against the rules of the church. He should accept the treatments he is getting the way the priest governor happily accepted his suspension and the way the other married priest also accepted his suspension. There is no need to whip up sentiments and play on the emotions of people. When an institution you are under stops no longer agrees with your personal convictions, instead of sticking on and having identity crises, it's better to withdraw and actualize your full potential. Both Rev. Prof. Martins Paul Obayi and Most. Rev. Prof. Igwebuike Godfrey Onah are great sons of Nsukka who have brought good things to the diocese and the community. It's important that they continue to do their good works for the zone and not be hindered by Dogma. If the Okunerere Adoration Ministry work is more important for Fr. Paul than his priestly calling, he should tow the way of Fr. Hyacinth Iormem Alia, who believes that rescuing Benue State is more important than his priestly calling at least for the next 8 years. He should step down and focus on the Adoration so he can be free from the Church the way (truncated)

For the past week, news from Israel and Gaza has been distressing. When news events like conflict, natural disasters, pandemics and other tragedies reach our screens, it can cause a lot of anxiety and even a sense of hopelessness. For people living with dementia, the constant stream of images on the news may cause additional worry and feel overwhelming ‚Äì perhaps because it brings back personal memories of their own distressing experiences, such as living through previous times of conflict or tragedy. We can‚Äôt make the news go away, but we do have some tips for dealing with it. The 24-hour news cycle can make it difficult to switch off, so try to limit how much you read, watch or listen to. Take care of your mental health. If you or someone you support is struggling with stress or anxiety that is affecting your ability to function properly, or you are feeling very low, then contact your GP for help. Or call our Dementia support line if you are lonely or afraid and need a chat. Understand a person may be 'time-shifting; and their experience may be that they are living at an earlier time in their life. They may become disorientated and confused about time and place. Try to accept the reality of the person with dementia, listen to them, and try to understand their past. Alzheimer‚Äôs Society is here for you, whatever your question. We can answer queries about all aspects of dementia and offer advice and support for all associated challenges, including dealing with anxiety and being overwhelmed. Call us on 0333 150 3456

The Government of St. Vincent and the Grenadines (GOSVG) says "war crimes" are being committed in the ongoing Israeli-Gaza conflict and has called for an end to hostilities on both sides. The government made the call in a statement on Friday, five days after the regional bloc, CARICOM, said "the savage nature of the attacks and counterattacks is the antithesis of civilised life and living"....

ICAHD Statement on Hamas incursion and
Israel's disproportionate retaliation
 

ICAHD (Israeli Coalition Against Home Demolition) mourns the loss of all lives, Israeli and Palestinian, whether in the Hamas incursion or in the course of Israel‚Äôs disproportionate retaliation. All lives are precious, period. Precisely for that reason, however, we need to emphasize the political context if we hope to ever achieve a substantially just resolution and prevent further deaths and suffering.

The context is clear. The Palestinians have never been at war with Jews; they have been resisting a unilateral settler colonial project whose declared aim is the take-over of their homeland, the transformation of Palestine into Israel and the erasure of the Palestinian people, its culture and heritage. Calls to ‚Äúend the violence‚Äù are not enough. On the contrary, they create a false dichotomy between military conquest, occupation, displacement, repression and the war crimes of a settler state on the one hand and the resistance of a colonized people with no state of their own, no army and no support from the major political powers on the other. Under the guise of ‚Äúsecurity‚Äù and ‚Äúself-defense,‚Äù the United States and Europe have supported Israel‚Äôs killing and displacement of Palestinians ‚Äì routinely described as ‚Äúterrorists‚Äù ‚Äì while ignoring and even justifying Israeli state terrorism.

The only way to end the violence and save all lives in Palestine/Israel is to decolonize the oppressive apartheid regime and its occupation, replacing them with a democratic state offering equal rights for all. We realize that in the midst of the ongoing events there exists no space for talk of a just political settlement and ‚Äúpeace.‚Äù But Israel can neither complete its settler project nor erase the Palestinian people, and no Palestinians should be killed or displaced in its futile attempt to do so. Nor can Palestinians achieve their liberation from an infinitely stronger Israel through armed struggle.

We call on Israel to stop its genocidal revenge attacks on Gaza, and certainly not to mount a ground invasion. We call on progressive forces everywhere to change the narrative. No longer should we speak of a ‚Äúconflict‚Äù in which Palestinian resistance is criminalized and Israel‚Äôs expansion through military means is cast as its ‚Äúright of self-defense.‚Äù Only a shift to an anti-colonial narrative will enable the emergence of a just, peaceful and secure post-colonial state and shared society out of the pools of blood in which we wallow.

October 14, 2023 Feast day of Pope St. Callistus I Pope St. Callistus I please pray for us. *Also known as* * Callixtus I * Calixtus I *[Memorial](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/feasts)* * [14 October](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/14-october) *Profile* > Born a [slave](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/patrons-of-slaves), owned by Carpophorus, a [Christian](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/christianity) in the household of Caesar. His master entrusted a large sum to Callistus to open a [bank](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/patrons-of-bankers), which took in several deposits, made several loans to people who refused to pay them back, and went broke. Knowing he would be personally blamed and punished, Callistus fled, but was [caught](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/patrons-of-prisoners) and returned to his owner. Several depositors begged for his life, believing he had not lost the money, but had stolen and hid it. They were wrong; he wasn‚Äôt a [thief](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/patrons-of-reformed-thieves), just a victim, but he was sentenced to work the [tin mines](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/patrons-of-tin-miners). By a quirk of Roman law, the ownership of Callistus was transferred from Carpophorus to the state, and when he was later ransomed out of his sentence with a number of other [Christians](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/christianity), he became a free man. [Pope](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/patrons-of-popes) [Zephyrinus](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/pope-zephyrinus) put Callistus [in charge](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/patrons-of-cemetery-workers) of the Roman public burial grounds, today still called the *Cemetery of Saint Callistus*. [Archdeacon](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/archdeacon). Sixteenth [Pope](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/patrons-of-popes).Most of what we know about him has come down to us from his critics, including an [anti-Pope](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/anti-pope) of the day. Callistus was on more than one occasion accused of [heresy](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/heresy) for such actions as permitting a return to [Communion](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/holy-communion) for sinners who had repented and done penance, or for proclaiming that differences in economic class were no barrier to [marriage](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/matrimony). This last put him in conflict with Roman civil law, but he stated that in matters concerning the [Church](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/catholic-church) and the [sacraments](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/sacrament), [Church](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/catholic-church)[law](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/patrons-of-canonists) trumped civil [law](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/patrons-of-lawyers). In both cases he taught what the [Church](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/catholic-church) has taught for centuries, including today, and though a whole host of [schismatics](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/schism) [wrote](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/patrons-of-writers) against him, his crime seems to have been to practice orthodox [Christianity](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/christianity). [Martyred](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/patrons-of-martyrs) in the [persecutions](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/persecutions) of [Alexander Severus](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/emperor-alexander-severus). *[Papal](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/patrons-of-popes) Ascension* * c.[218](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/time-line-218) *[Died](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/patrons-of-martyrs)* * [martyred](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/patrons-of-martyrs) c.[223](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/time-line-223) * legend says he was [killed](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/patrons-of-martyrs) by being thrown down a well with a millstone around his neck, but there is no solid evidence *[Canonized](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/canonization)* * [Pre-Congregation](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/pre-congregation) *[Patronage](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/patron-saints)* * [cemetery workers](https://catholicsaints.info/pope-saint-callistus-i/patrons-of-cemetery-workers) (truncated)

You see, our minds are fragmented, broken up - the business mind, the religious mind, the family mind, the corrupt mind, the ideological mind, the religious mind, and so on - it is broken up. And thought is responsible for this breaking up. And thought assumes a certain responsibility and says, 'I am different from the thing which I observe'. That is, I am not envy, because I can control envy, I can shape envy, I can run away from envy, but it cannot change envy because it is a fragment of itself. Envy is a fragment of the observer who says, 'I am different from envy'. So, when the observer is the observed then there is no conflict, which means no duality at all, and therefore there is instant action without friction.

Now, if you have listened to this with your heart and with your mind, with care and attention, which means with affection, then you are learning a great deal. Not from the speaker; the speaker cannot teach you. You are both the teacher and the disciple. And if you have heard what was said it's yours. If you have not heard then it is another's, and when you repeat another, something which others have said, you are utterly second-hand human beings. So don't repeat anything that you yourself have not known directly by your understanding of yourself. That's the first thing to learn: don't repeat a thing, either from the Gita - never! Only that which you know, which you have understood by examining yourself. Then you will find out the extraordinary subtleties, the beauty, the immensity of that. It's like looking at an expanding flower. When you know how to look at a flower with eyes that are full of care and love and affection, that flower begins to unfold, show its greatness, its beauty, its perfume. In the same way, when you know, when you can look at yourself, it reveals tremendous things, and therein lies the beauty of living.   KRISHNAMURTI

Introducing @2faced_sa - A Musical Odyssey Inspired by the Janus Concept!

In ancient Roman mythology, Janus, the god of beginnings and transitions, gazed in two opposite directions, symbolizing the duality of time, doorways, and endings. Just as Janus presided over the ebb and flow of conflict, "2Faced" brings together two distinct musical genres, amapiano and gqom, in a harmonious fusion.

Meet the masterminds behind this musical journey: Thuli P, a renowned actress turned amapiano DJ, and Slenda da dancing DJ, an iconic dancer turned gqom DJ. Prepare to be enticed by this unique experience where two genres unite on stage, creating a mesmerizing musical fusion. @2faced_sa invites you to embrace the duality of sound and embark on a musical journey like no other.

"It‚Äôs been a dreadful week. Humanity must prevail.

Civilians in Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territory are suffering from a week of utter anguish and devastation. I fear that the worst is yet to come. 

In Israel, families are reeling from the horror of last Saturday‚Äôs attack. More than a thousand people have been killed and many more have been injured. Over 100 people are held captive. 

In Gaza, families have been bombed while inching their way south along congested, damaged roads, following an evacuation order that left hundreds of thousands of people scrambling for safety but with nowhere to go.
 
Nearly 2,000 people have been killed and many more have been injured. 

There is no power, no water and no fuel. Food supplies are running dangerously low.

Hospitals, overwhelmed with patients, are running out of medicine. 

Morgues are overflowing. 

Homes, schools, shelters, health centers and places of worship are under intense bombardment. 

Entire residential neighbourhoods have been razed to the ground. 
Aid workers have been killed.

The humanitarian situation in Gaza, already critical, is fast becoming untenable.

In the West Bank, violence is on the rise, with a surge in civilian deaths and injuries. Families are facing ever greater movement restrictions.

And in Lebanon, the risk of the conflict spilling into the country is a major concern. 

The parties‚Äô actions and rhetoric over the past few days are extremely alarming and unacceptable.

Even wars have rules, and these rules must be upheld, at all times, and by all sides.

Civilians and civilian infrastructure, including humanitarian workers and assets, must be protected. 

Civilians must be allowed to leave for safer areas. And whether they move or stay, constant care must be taken to spare them.

Essential supplies and services and unimpeded humanitarian access must be allowed.

Anyone held captive must be treated humanely. All hostages must be released. 

All countries with influence must exert it to ensure respect for the rules of war and to avoid any further escalation and spillover. 

The past week has been a test for humanity, and humanity is failing."

Statement by Martin Griffiths

Toni Morrison was one of 18 writers who co-wrote and signed a letter as a call to resist Israel's undeclared political aim: the liquidation of the Palestinian state.

The letter was published on 
August 18, 2006 in The Nation.

The letter reads:

‚ÄúThe latest chapter of the conflict between Israel and Palestine began when Israeli forces abducted two civilians, a doctor and his brother, from Gaza. An incident scarcely reported anywhere, except in the Turkish press. The following day the Palestinians took an Israeli soldier prisoner‚Äìand proposed a negotiated exchange against prisoners taken by the Israelis‚Äìthere are approximately 10,000 in Israeli jails.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat this ‚Äúkidnapping‚Äù was considered an outrage, whereas the illegal military occupation of the West Bank and the systematic appropriation of its natural resources‚Äìmost particularly that of water‚Äìby the Israeli Defense (!) Forces is considered a regrettable but realistic fact of life, is typical of the double standards repeatedly employed by the West in face of what has befallen the Palestinians, on the land allotted to them by international agreements, during the last seventy years.‚Äù

‚ÄúToday outrage follows outrage; makeshift missiles cross sophisticated ones. The latter usually find their target situated where the disinherited and crowded poor live, waiting for what was once called Justice. Both categories of missile rip bodies apart horribly‚Äìwho but field commanders can forget this for a moment?‚Äù

‚ÄúEach provocation and counter-provocation is contested and preached over. But the subsequent arguments, accusations and vows, all serve as a distraction in order to divert world attention from a long-term military, economic and geographic practice whose political aim is nothing less than the liquidation of the Palestinian nation.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis has to be said loud and clear, for the practice, only half declared and often covert, is advancing fast these days, and, in our opinion, it must be unceasingly and eternally recognized for what it is and resisted.‚Äù

PS: As Juliano Mer Khamis, director of the documentary film Arna‚Äôs Children, asked: ‚ÄúWho is going to paint the ‚ÄòGuernica‚Äô of Lebanon?‚Äù

Thousands of protesters poured onto the streets of central London on Saturday to demand that Israel halt its bombing campaign and siege of the Gaza Strip as it prepares for a possible ground invasion of the tiny Palestinian enclave.

Undeterred by warnings against waving the Palestinian flag, the protesters gathered outside the BBC‚Äôs New Broadcasting House to denounce what they called ‚ÄúIsraeli agression‚Äù, as air strikes pounded the Gaza Strip for an eighth successive day.

Earlier on Saturday, the exterior of BBC studios in London was sprayed with red paint in protest against the channel‚Äôs coverage of the conflict. Middle East Eye contacted the BBC for comment but did not receive a response by time of publication.

At the rally - organised by Friends of Al-Aqsa, Muslim Association of Britain (MAB) and other groups - pro-Palestinian protesters could be heard chanting ‚ÄúIsrael is a terrorist state‚Äù and ‚Äúfree Palestine‚Äù as they moved from Regent Street, one of London‚Äôs main shopping thoroughfares, towards Westminster.

More than 1,000 police were deployed ahead of the protest, with the Metropolitan police warning that anyone showing support for Hamas, a group proscribed as a terrorist organisation in the UK, or deviating from the protest route could face arrest.

"As much as we think that this is about war and conflict and perpetual animosities, this is about land and water. And there is only one viable future. We either all live together, or we all die together...Military solution will not produce an outcome of a viable future for anybody," says Palestinian human rights attorney Noura Erakat, who calls for deescalation, ceasefire and international sanctions to pressure Israel to end its military assault and occupation and to preserve life for all Palestinians and Israelis.

I posted that message at the beginning of the week on my other social media pages and in my stories here. A few days later, this mother contacted me. She wanted to reconnect, thank me for sharing about her, and assure me that she and her son are safe. I was beyond grateful. Later I asked if she‚Äôd consider sharing‚Äîfor the benefit of other parents everywhere‚Äîwhat she had done to help her son through his fears. Here‚Äôs what she so generously shared:

‚ÄúI consulted with Janet a few years ago because of a unique problem. We were under attack by rockets launched at Israel. There were many families affected by this and alarm sirens were blasting many times a day at random hours signaling for us that we had a minute to get to shelter so we didn't get hit.

I hadn‚Äôt told my then 4 year old son the truth about what was happening, I made something up and tried to downplay the whole situation as if everything was normal. I didn‚Äôt want him to be scared or traumatized so for the days that followed my husband and I refrained from talking about it in front of him and we did our best to dodge his questions or outright lie about it. Looking back I am sure that the message he got from us was that we ourselves were uncertain, confused and couldn‚Äôt handle what was going on (we really couldn't but we were trying to act like we were, and he could see right through us). As a result, my son became extremely clingy, highly sensitive and prone to outbursts. He jumped at every sound he heard.
I worked on the following things following my consultations with Janet on the subject:
1.¬†Telling my son the truth in an age-appropriate way. We worked on the actual wording like ‚Äúthis conflict has been going on for a long time‚Äù (to give him context), ‚Äúhearing the alarms and the explosions can be really scary‚Äù (since that was what I observed he was feeling), and other things like that. Janet also made the point that I can‚Äôt protect him from hearing what he hears from friends and other family members and that it‚Äôs of utmost importance he knows we talk about EVERYTHING in our household. (Continued in comments)

...Rabbi Dov Greenberg, executive director of Rohr Chabad House, Stanford‚Äôs Jewish community center, told CNN the students were ‚Äúshaken up.‚Äù

According to Greenberg, the students said the instructor tried to justify the actions of Hamas and asked the students how many Jews were killed in the Holocaust.

After one student answered ‚Äú6 million,‚Äù the instructor then said more people have been killed by colonizers and said, ‚ÄúIsrael is a colonizer.‚Äù

The instructor then illustrated his point by asking some students to physically go to the back of class. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what Israel does to Palestinians,‚Äù the teacher said, according to Greenberg...

...The Stanford instructor‚Äôs alleged comments came during two classes Tuesday, with a total of 18 students, during which the instructor announced the day‚Äôs lesson would focus on colonialism, the San Francisco Chronicle reported...

...Students [said] the instructor brought up the colonization of Congo by Belgium‚Äôs King Leopold II in the 19th century and said more people were killed then than during the Holocaust, and Israel had colonized Palestinians, the Chronicle reported.

Students from both classes told Cohen and Mandelshtam the instructor asked students where their ancestors were from and labeled them as a ‚Äúcolonizer‚Äù or ‚Äúcolonized,‚Äù according to the Chronicle"

I flew to Jordan, Qatar, Bahrain, and Saudi Arabia for meetings with our partners. It is our collective goal to prevent any state or non-state actors from creating a new front in this conflict. In all of my conversations, our friends and partners throughout the region have agreed that there can be no more business as usual with Hamas. 

We know the humanitarian situation is urgent. Efforts to get humanitarian aid into Gaza are complicated by the fact that Hamas continues to use innocent civilians as human shields and is reportedly blocking roads to prevent Palestinians from moving to southern Gaza, out of harm‚Äôs way. 

Regardless of these challenges, we are actively working with partners, @UN relief agencies, the @ICRC, and others to address the acute humanitarian needs of people in Gaza ‚Äì to protect civilians from harm and ensure that they have the ability to get what they need. 

Let us not lose sight of why this is happening. 

Israel is conducting operations in Gaza because Hamas‚Äîa terrorist organization‚Äîattacked, slaughtered, raped, mutilated, tortured, and burned innocent civilians. We continue to discuss with Israel the importance of taking every possible precaution to avoid harming civilians while exercising its right to defend its people‚Äîand to try to ensure that Hamas can never repeat what it‚Äôs done. 

For Americans in Israel who wish to depart, our @StateDept team is chartering flights to provide additional options. The first flight carrying U.S. citizens and their immediate family members from Israel is wheels down in Athens. Our work will continue. 

As we finish this day and look to the next, know that we are working intensively to secure the release of hostages, including American citizens held by Hamas in Gaza. 

I carry the discussions I had with the families of the people held hostage by Hamas with me as I fly from country to country. 

Their‚Äîand our‚Äîanguish is profound and we know they are desperate to be with their loved ones. We are working urgently to bring people home. We are doing that with allies and partners across the region, and I am grateful that the international partners I am meeting with share this collective urgency.

‚ÄòHigh time for a revision‚Äô ‚Äî Dutch cartoon (1961) illustrating Dutch and Indonesian perspectives of one another: the Dutchman sees the Indonesian as a raging communist bearing down upon an angelic Dutch civilian, while the Indonesian sees the Dutchman as a raging colonialist bearing down upon an angelic Indonesian civilian. The cartoon was drawn by Fritz Behrendt for Algemeen Handelsblad newspaper at a time of deteriorating relations between the two countries, Indonesia having severed ties with the Netherlands the year before over the ongoing West New Guinea dispute. Dutch New Guinea had remained part of the Netherlands following Indonesian independence and would be a persistent point of contention through the 1950s, escalating in 1960-62 to near-open conflict before the New York Agreement of August 1962, which ended with the Netherlands ceding the territory to Indonesia.

On Saturday, central London witnessed a significant gathering of protesters numbering in the thousands. Their unified demand was clear: they called for an immediate cessation of Israel's bombing campaign and the siege on the Gaza Strip, all while expressing concerns about a potential ground invasion of this small Palestinian territory.

Unfazed by warnings against displaying the Palestinian flag, demonstrators assembled outside the BBC's New Broadcasting House to voice their condemnation of what they deemed "Israeli aggression." This demonstration unfolded amidst ongoing airstrikes in the Gaza Strip, which had persisted for an eighth consecutive day.

Earlier that same day, BBC studios in London became the target of a protest, with the exterior of the building being splattered with red paint. This act was carried out in protest against the channel's coverage of the conflict. When Middle East Eye sought a response from the BBC, no comment had been received by the time of publication.

This rally, organized by Friends of Al-Aqsa, the Muslim Association of Britain (MAB), and other affiliated groups, resonated with pro-Palestinian voices. Chants of "Israel is a terrorist state" and "free Palestine" echoed as the protesters made their way from Regent Street, one of London's major shopping avenues, toward Westminster.

In preparation for the event, more than 1,000 police officers were deployed, and the Metropolitan Police issued warnings. They cautioned that individuals showing support for Hamas, a group designated as a terrorist organization in the UK, or deviating from the approved protest route could face potential arrest.

In the wake of the recent surge in tensions between Palestinian militant groups and Israel, acclaimed Israeli-Kenyan musician, Gilad Millo, took to social media to share a message reflecting the impact of the conflict on his family. 

In an Instagram video, Gilad conveyed a personal account of the situation, detailing how his son, Omer, had made the courageous decision to return to Israel and join his paratrooper unit as an IDF reservist.

"Our son Omer landed in Israel to join his paratrooper unit as a reservist in @idf," Gilad shared in his touching message.

Despite the challenges posed by flight cancellations and the escalating crisis, Omer found a way to make his way back to his homeland to serve alongside his sister, Lia, who is also a soldier in the IDF. Lia had been actively involved in training combat medical teams in preparation for the ongoing conflict.

The decision made by Omer and Lia to serve in the Israeli army stemmed from a deep sense of duty and responsibility. Having grown up in Kenya, the siblings have been deeply affected by the tragic events that have unfolded, having lost friends and acquaintances in the devastating attacks.

Gilad and his wife expressed their profound pride and admiration for their children, acknowledging their remarkable strength and character.

"In dealing with conflict, we should first contemplate that our adversary wants to be happy and be free from suffering, just as we do. 

Next, try to see things from their point of view. By looking at the situation from their perspective, we‚Äôll be able to see clearly who has the mistaken idea, and who is in error. We will be able to see our own faults clearly, too. If, through this contemplation, we find that we are the ones in error, then we can begin to address those faults in ourselves. Should we confirm that yes, the other person is the one who is confused and at fault, we‚Äôll still be able to see the situation with compassion. 

We‚Äôll recognize that they are trying for happiness, but they misunderstand how to attain it. They might be harming us, and others too, yet we can understand that their behavior is actually impeding the happiness that they‚Äôre trying to achieve." -Mingyur Rinpoche

‚ÄúFirst Memories‚Äù 10.09.2023, North Carolina

‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢

The tiny apartment on the right is where I lived with my parents & brother from 1973 to 1975. I was 4 years old when I left there- this is where my first memories are from. Until the other day, I hadn‚Äôt seen it in 42 years, but everything looked exactly as I remembered. We had very little money & it was quite small, but it was more than enough. My first memories are good ones, a happy time with our little family‚Äî I am grateful for that. When I looked to the sky, I only saw a beautiful blue. 

Bombs did not fall from the warplanes of a neighboring state to level my neighborhood, nor did armed men descend on paragliders to execute my family. 

Once again, I am grateful. 

But these horrors will be the first clear memories many children will have for the rest of their lives. We call them Jewish & Muslim, Palestinian & Israeli... do you think at 2, 3, or 4 years old, those kids have any conception of what those terms mean? But in the midst of this living hell, their nascent awareness of the world is being born. This will stay with them forever, shaping their identity- their childhood is a killing field, & they will grow up soaked in bloody memories. 

What kind of adults will be formed by this?

We ignore history & human nature at our own peril.

I am not an expert on Middle Eastern affairs (or anything else), but I do know this: this is not a sports match on tv. Remember that. Global geopolitical stability is already very fragile, & without rapid deescalation, conflict could expand swiftly to engulf the entire region, then spread outwards to encompass the entire planet. The dominos are stacked up & ready to fall- it‚Äôs happened before, & make no mistake, it can happen again.

Marinate on that for a second.

Whatever your beliefs- any sane, pragmatic person should be calling for an immediate ceasefire, release of Israeli hostages, & humanitarian aid to be allowed into Gaza. This will not stop otherwise. It‚Äôs been a week of CONSTANT DEATH- haven‚Äôt enough children died? 

The current trajectory is not viable for anything other than our potential annihilation. 

We must not lose sight of this. 

ENOUGH. 

üíî

Violence begets violence. This hatred is handed down through generations, with children conditioned to loathe and fear the "other." I have experienced this first hand; both of my parents are refugees of war, my mother's brother is considered a 'hero' as he died for his country. 

To genuinely address wars, we must first eradicate all conflict from our own lives, both internal and external. 

And for that to happen you must be nobody, belong nowhere hence belong everywhere. Only then you are a whole human being. Only then you shall know peace and love.  Not the love for your family or your country, but love. 
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
#spirituality#innerpeace#innerpeace#love#wisdom#palestineisrael#war#freedomfromthemadness

Just as AI has its own biases (this image was generated with Midjourney, an AI generator), humans too have their inherent biases. The true essence of humanity lies in overcoming these biases through empathy. While it's natural to have biases, without empathy, these biases can escalate into extreme cruelty.

This isn't a message to influence or persuade. It's merely a personal reflection on the influential powers that dominate our world. The entities that champion liberty and freedom often falter in their representation of events, as I've witnessed this in Egypt before, where the repercussions of media misrepresentation still reverberate.The potential for media to twist reality and thereby influence life-altering events is something many may not fully grasp. I've personally realized the extent of media bias this year. The idea that influential media outlets can be swayed by xenophobia, political agendas, and other biases is deeply troubling. When these outlets propagate messages of hate, choose sides rather than standing with humanity, or dehumanize anyone who doesn't align with their narrative, it's concerning.

While human conflict has been a constant throughout history, the amplification of these conflicts by biased media narratives has repeatedly threatened the fabric of our civilizations.

I don't ask you to align with any specific side, but to value innocent human lives above all. Take a moment to step out of your digital bubble and its media narratives. Conduct your own research, understand the other side. Because contrary to what many have been led to believe, they are human too.

‚ÄúWhere can I turn for peace?
Where is my solace
When other sources cease to make me whole?
When with a wounded heart, anger, or malice,
I draw myself apart,
Searching my soul?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhere, when my aching grows,
Where, when I languish,
Where, in my need to know, where can I run?‚Äù

This song brought me solace as a kid & certainly fed into my belief that running was the solution to most of my challenges. And it worked / has worked in most cases.

The sad part, however, is that those who are currently suffering have nowhere to run.

We all deserve peace. We all deserve a place of refuge. We all deserve time & space to live & work & worship & recreate, but that isn‚Äôt the reality for millions of innocent victims of this age old conflict.

I don‚Äôt claim to have the answers & I recognize the irony of sharing the words of a religious hymn when it is religion that is being used to justify the mobilization, militarization & brutalization of the masses.

I am also keenly aware that I am descended from colonizers. I am not native to this land or these places to which I run & in which I find refuge.

I do know that nationalism, militarism, racism & colonialism / imperialism are not the answer, but rather the cause of the current condition & as long as they continue to be supported financially & with our silence, the conflict, instability & brutality will grow worse. That makes me sad because I don‚Äôt see either side willing to see the other as human despite historically (according to sacred texts from all three religions) being descended from the same person.

For what it‚Äôs worth, here are a few photos of where I run most days in my efforts to find peace within myself & others. My hope is that we each have the opportunity to do the same in our own lives & we do everything in our power to enable & encourage others to do the same.

‚ÄúFree, Free Palestine!‚Äù

Around a hundred people turned up waving Palestinian flags and signs in solidarity with Palestinians amid the brutal conflict with Israel that erupted last week.

‚ÄúEnd genocide! End genocide!‚Äù they shouted.

‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt do anything from here. Every time I open Facebook, there‚Äôs someone I know who is killed, or a friend posting about losing a loved one,‚Äù a woman from the Arabic Culture Information Society who organised the protest cried. 

‚ÄúWould you, Maltese accept to be told to leave your country?‚Äù 

The ACIS said that the demonstration was organised ‚Äúto protest the indiscriminate bombardment and unlawful siege of civilians in the Gaza Strip‚Äù which became an open-air prison with 2.2 million inhabitants.

Yesterday, Israel warned 1.1 million Gaza residents to evacuate within 24 hours. The move has been decried by the UN as ‚Äúimpossible‚Äù. 

On 7th October, Hamas killed at least 260 festival goers in Israel. Israel has retaliated with airstrikes that have killed at least 1,500 Palestinians, with nearly 7,700 wounded. The death toll in Israeli, meanwhile, has reached some 1,300.

Amid a heavy retaliatory air and artillery assault by Israel against the Gaza Strip on October 10, Israel Defense Forces spokesperson Avichay Adraee posted a message on Facebook to residents of the al-Daraj neighborhood, urging them to leave their homes in advance of impending airstrikes.‚Å†
‚Å†
It‚Äôs not clear how most people in al-Daraj were supposed to see the warning: Intense fighting and electrical shortages have strangled Palestinian access to the internet, putting besieged civilians at even greater risk.‚Å†
‚Å†
Following Hamas‚Äôs grisly surprise attack across the Gaza border on October 7, the Israeli counterattack left the two million Palestinians who call the area home struggling to connect to the internet at a time when access to current information is crucial and potentially lifesaving.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúShutting down the internet in armed conflict is putting civilians at risk,‚Äù Deborah Brown, a senior researcher at Human Rights Watch, told The Intercept. ‚ÄúIt could help contribute to injury or death because people communicate around what are safe places and conditions.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
According to companies and research organizations that monitor the global flow of internet traffic, Gazan access to the internet has dramatically dropped since Israeli strikes began, with data service cut entirely for some customers.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúMy sense is that very few people in Gaza have internet service,‚Äù Doug Madory of the internet monitoring firm Kentik told The Intercept. Madory said he spoke to a contact working with an internet service provider in Gaza who told him that internet access has been reduced by 80 to 90 percent because of a lack of fuel and power, and airstrikes.‚Å†
‚Å†
As for causes of the outages, Marwa Fatafta, a policy analyst with the digital rights group Access Now, cited Israeli strikes against office buildings housing Gazan telecommunications firms, such as the now-demolished Al-Watan Tower, as a major factor, in addition to damage to the electrical grid.‚Å†
‚Å†
Fatafta told The Intercept, ‚ÄúThere is a near complete information blackout from Gaza.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†

Three heads are better than one.‚Å£
‚Å£
Cheetahs are generally solitary cats, except when females are raising cubs or males join forces to form hunting coalitions. This trio of youngsters are yet to disperse in search of territory of their own, and when they do, they will face a litany of threats, not least of which will come from human-wildlife conflict. The cheetah is leading the race when it comes to being Africa's most endangered big cat. Eradicated from over 90% of its historic range, the cheetah's wide-ranging nature and vulnerability to competition from rival predators intensify the risks it faces. If we are to give the cheetah a fighting chance at survival, we must protect crucial habitats and address the root causes of human-wildlife conflict.‚Å£

Australia is providing an initial $10 million in humanitarian assistance for civilians affected by the conflict in Gaza.

Australia will provide $3 million to the International Committee of the Red Cross to fund urgent needs like restoring essential services and providing medical support to victims of the conflict.

Through United Nations agencies, Australia will provide $7 million to deliver critical support including emergency water, nutrition, sanitation and hygiene services, as well as child protection.

Australia will continue to monitor and assess the humanitarian situation and stands ready to provide further support.

‚ÄúWe have seen devastating loss of innocent life since the heinous attacks on Israel by brutal terrorist group Hamas.

‚ÄúFar from representing the Palestinian people, Hamas undermines Palestinian needs and aspirations.

‚ÄúWe continue to call for the unconditional release of all hostages. We stand with Israel and reiterate its right to defend itself.

‚ÄúPresident Biden has called on Israel to operate by the rules of war in its response to Hamas attacks - we join him and others in that call.

‚ÄúWe call for safe and unimpeded humanitarian access to civilians affected by the worsening humanitarian crisis in Gaza.

‚ÄúAdherence to international humanitarian law must be prioritised - including the protection of civilians, wherever they live.‚Äù

Quote attributable to Minister for International Development and the Pacific, the Hon Pat Conroy MP:

‚ÄúAustralia‚Äôs contribution through our trusted partners supports the humanitarian crisis affecting civilians caught up in this conflict.

‚ÄúOur assistance will prioritise the immediate needs of civilians, ensuring support reaches those most in need.

‚ÄúWe call for the protection of, and unimpeded access for, humanitarian workers who are delivering lifesaving support.‚Äù

Israel‚Äôs evacuation order is creating chaos in Gaza. A ground invasion will be worse.

The situation on the ground in Gaza is ‚Äúfast becoming untenable,‚Äù Martin Griffiths, the @un_ocha chief, said in a statement Saturday. 

On Monday, the Israeli government shut off Gaza‚Äôs access to water, electricity, and fuel as part of its declared siege of the region. Gaza has been under blockade by both Israel and Egypt since 2007, and access to basic goods, including food and medicine, is available only via the UN and nongovernmental organizations.

‚ÄúI fear that the worst is yet to come,‚Äù Griffiths added.

Since Hamas, the militant Islamic group that has controlled Gaza since 2007, launched an unprecedented and brutal attack against Israel that killed at least 1,300 people a week ago, the Israeli Air Force (IAF) has dropped at least 6,000 bombs over Gaza. Those operations have so far killed more than 1,500 Palestinians, including civilians. Meanwhile, an IDF ground invasion seems imminent.

More than 2 million Gazans live in a strip of land the size of Philadelphia, making it one of the most densely populated places on the planet, which increases the possibility of hitting civilians during military operations. And about 42.5 percent of the population is under the age of 14, making childhood casualties common in times of conflict.

Supplies like food, fuel, medicine, and clean water are already running critically low in the region, and as of yet, since borders remain closed, there is no humanitarian corridor to get supplies into Gaza ‚Äî or get people out.

U.S. Army Hawk anti-aircraft missiles pointed out over the Florida Straits in Key West, Florida, on October 27, 1962, during the Cuban Missile Crisis. On this day in 1962, an American U-2 spy plane took hundreds of photos of nuclear missile sites being built by the Soviet Union on the island of Cuba. The Cuban Missile Crisis was a tense and dangerous confrontation between the United States, the Soviet Union, and Cuba in October 1962. 

It is considered one of the most critical moments of the Cold War and brought the world to the brink of nuclear war. The crisis began when the United States discovered that the Soviet Union was secretly deploying nuclear missiles in Cuba, just 90 miles off the coast of Florida. Upon learning of the Soviet missile installations in Cuba, U.S. President John F. Kennedy and his advisors debated the best course of action. 

They considered various options, including diplomacy, a surgical air strike on the missile sites, and a full-scale invasion of Cuba. Kennedy decided on a naval blockade, known as a "quarantine," to prevent further Soviet shipments of military equipment to Cuba. Tensions escalated rapidly as both the United States and the Soviet Union prepared for potential military conflict. For 13 days, the world watched anxiously, fearing the outbreak of nuclear war.

President Kennedy addressed the nation in a televised speech on October 22, 1962, informing the public about the crisis and announcing the quarantine. He said: "It shall be the policy of this nation to regard any nuclear missile launched from Cuba against any nation in the Western Hemisphere as an attack by the Soviet Union on the United States, requiring a full retaliatory response upon the Soviet Union."

Diplomatic negotiations took place behind the scenes, with Kennedy and Soviet Premier Nikita Khrushchev exchanging letters and messages to find a peaceful resolution. In a critical moment, Khrushchev agreed to dismantle the missile sites in Cuba in exchange for a public pledge from the United States not to invade Cuba and a secret agreement to remove American missiles from Turkey. This agreement, reached in late October 1962, resolved the immediate crisis.

On 14 October 1066 the armies of William, the Duke of Normandy, and the Anglo-Saxon King Harold Godwinson clashed near Hastings, in one of the most famous battles in history and one that would decide the fate of the English throne.

Unusually for battles of the time, the clash at Hastings lasted all day. The conflict was only ended by groups of Anglo-Saxon warriors breaking discipline and charging from out of their shield wall. They were then surrounded, cut off, before being cut down by Norman warriors. Late in the day, the Anglo-Saxon King Harold was hit in the eye with an arrow. It was a fatal blow. With their king dead, the retreating Anglo-Saxons were defeated. The Normans were victorious.

Learn more with our 1066 Collection, featuring documentaries and podcasts on different aspects of the clash - from the role of archers on the battlefield to the Bayeux Tapestry. Sign up for 50% off your first 3 months via the link in the bio.

His Highness Prince Faisal Alfarhan received Secretary of State Anthony Blinken to discuss in Riyadh . During the meeting, the Saudi Foreign Minister reiterated that the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia strongly rejects any calls for the forced displacement of the Palestinian people from Gaza and condemns targeting civilians in any form. The minister stressed that the Kingdom calls for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza and its surrounding areas, lifting the siege on Gaza as per the international law, and ensuring the entry of urgent humanitarian aid, such as food and medicine.
 He emphasized the importance of taking swift collective action to end the ongoing cycle of violence and all forms of military escalation against civilians to prevent a humanitarian catastrophe.
 Prince Faisal emphasized the urgent need to prevent more innocent civilians from falling victim to the ongoing cycle of violence. He stressed that Israel must abide by international humanitarian law and avoid any actions that contradict it, as such actions will only worsen the current crisis and increase the suffering in the region.
 He also underlined that dialogue is the only way to achieve a just and comprehensive political solution to the conflict. He called on the international community to fulfill its responsibility in stopping the violence and promoting the peace process as per the resolutions of the UN Security Council, the UN General Assembly, and the Arab Peace Initiative

As part of the humanitarian efforts undertaken by the UAE to provide urgent assistance to the Palestinian people, the UAE red crescent have launched a campaign to provide relief aid to the Palestinian people impacted by the war in the Gaza Strip, under the theme ‚ÄòTarahum - for Gaza‚Äô.

The campaign will be inaugurated on Sunday, 15th October 2023, in Abu Dhabi, under the supervision of the Emirates Red Crescent at the Abu Dhabi Ports Hall in Mina Zayed from 9 am - 4 pm, and will be organized across the rest of the Emirates at a later date.
this campaign aims to mitigate the severity of the humanitarian conditions, and alleviate the suffering of the most vulnerable groups, especially children, who constitute nearly half of the population of the Gaza Strip. More than one million children are affected by the current conflict, and the campaign will work towards providing children and mothers with basic needs, in addition to health supplies and general hygiene materials. 
The aid will be sent through the United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA) for Palestine Refugees in the Near East.

Pink Floyd - The Dark Side of the Moonüåà

The Dark Side of the Moon is the eighth studio album by the English rock band Pink Floyd, released on 1 March 1973 by Harvest Records. Primarily developed during live performances, the band premiered an early version of the record several months before recording began. The record was conceived as an album that focused on the pressures faced by the band during their arduous lifestyle, and dealing with the apparent mental health problems suffered by former band member Syd Barrett, who departed the group in 1968. New material was recorded in two sessions in 1972 and 1973 at Abbey Road Studios in London.

The record builds on ideas explored in Pink Floyd's earlier recordings and performances, while omitting the extended instrumentals that characterised their earlier work.

A concept album, the themes of The Dark Side of the Moon explore conflict, greed, time, death, and mental illness. Snippets from interviews with the band's road crew, as well as philosophical quotations, were also used. The sleeve, which depicts a prism spectrum, was designed by Storm Thorgerson, following keyboardist Richard Wright's request for a "simple and bold" design, representing the band's lighting and the album's themes. The album was promoted with two singles: "Money" and "Us and Them".

üìö Book Review: "The Veil of Corruption: The Virus of Beauty Book 2" by C.B. Lyall üìö

üåüüåüüåüüåüüåü (5/5 Stars)

Review:

üëâAs a teacher interacting with middle school students, I sometimes explore books outside my usual genres to recommend engaging reads to them. "The Veil of Corruption" had me stepping into the enchanting world of witches and wizards, and I must say, it was a spellbinding journey!

üëâThis is the second book in The Virus of Beauty series, and I strongly recommend starting with the first one to fully appreciate the intricate narrative. The story picks up seamlessly, plunging us deeper into a realm filled with magic, suspense, and captivating characters.

üëâThe conflict between witches and wizards adds a unique twist to the storyline, keeping me eagerly turning the pages to discover what unfolds next. What's truly remarkable is the author's skill in crafting a world that immerses readers completely. I found it nearly impossible to put the book down once I started.

üëâThe protagonist, Wilf, faces a whirlwind of challenges, from finding a cure for the Virus of Beauty to dealing with the corruption of the protective Veil that separates witches and wizards from the outside world. As his bond with the witch Katryna deepens, they are confronted by malevolent forces that kidnap her, setting Wilf on a mission to save not only the Magical Realm but also the one he cares for the most.

üëâ"The Veil of Corruption" is an outstanding young adult urban fantasy that delivers magic, action, adventure, and a whole lot more. The stakes are higher than ever, and the story's dramatic developments and suspenseful moments keep you on the edge of your seat.

üëâIf you're a fan of tightly woven, intriguing YA fantasies with originality, tension, and quirky characters, this series is a must-read! I can't wait to see where the next book in the series takes us.

Happy Reading! üìñ‚ú®üîÆ #BookReview #YABooks #FantasyFiction #MustReads

üìö BOOK REVIEW üìö 

"Consequential Urges" by Bruno Beaches is a gripping exploration of the human psyche under the weight of profound loss and internal conflict. The narrative, centered around the character Pablo, intricately weaves the complexities of grief, frustration, and the struggle for self-control.

Beaches artfully portrays Pablo's evolution, drawing readers into the tumultuous journey of a man who, despite his strength and power, grapples with inner demons. The thematic exploration of violence as a coping mechanism is both raw and poignant, offering readers a window into the darker recesses of the human soul.

The introduction of a psychologist adds depth to the narrative, providing a psychological lens through which Pablo attempts to unravel the complexities of his urges. This nuanced approach to mental health adds a layer of authenticity, as it delves into the internal struggles individuals face in the aftermath of profound loss.

The title, "Consequential Urges," hints at the inevitability of repercussions, and Beaches skillfully crafts a narrative that explores the law of unforeseen consequences. As Pablo's actions escalate, the story takes unexpected turns, keeping readers on the edge of their seats. The suspenseful build-up adds a layer of unpredictability, making each page turn a compelling experience.

The exploration of fate and the possibility of a surprise guardian angel introduces an element of hope, offering a glimmer of redemption in the face of self-destructive choices. Beaches masterfully navigates the delicate balance between despair and hope, creating a narrative that resonates with the complexities of the human condition.

In "Consequential Urges," Bruno Beaches delivers a thought-provoking tale that goes beyond a mere exploration of violence and consequences. It becomes a meditation on resilience, redemption, and the profound impact of unforeseen events on the human experience. Beaches' prose is both evocative and introspective, making this novel a compelling read for those who appreciate a blend of psychological depth and unpredictable storytelling.

Nearly eight in 10 Americans fear the war that erupted this week between Israel and Hamas will lead to a broader war in the Middle East, according to the latest PBS NewsHour/NPR/Marist poll.

With seven in 10 U.S. adults saying they are closely following what is happening, the anxiety about further escalation is shared across political affiliation, geography, gender, race, income, education and age. A third of U.S. adults said they were ‚Äúvery concerned‚Äù about wider violence in the region, according to this latest poll.

Hamas militants made an unprecedented incursion into Israel during the early hours of Oct. 7, firing thousands of rockets and sending fighters past Israel‚Äôs blockade of Gaza to launch  deadly attacks on several communities and take scores of hostages. The combined death toll from both the surprise assault as well as Israel‚Äôs bombardment of Gaza in response has risen to at least 2,800 lives.

On Friday, Israel ordered 1.1 million Palestinians in northern Gaza to evacuate in 24 hours, despite a warning from the United Nations that the short deadline could be disastrous. The evacuation orders come ahead of Israel‚Äôs anticipated ground invasion against Hamas. In recent days, Israel cut off food, water and electricity to the besieged area, where more than 2 million predominantly Palestinian residents have been ruled since 2007 by Hamas, which the United States has designated as a terrorist group.

The violent conflict has inflamed long-running animosity between Israel and its neighbors, with Turkey calling that nation‚Äôs response ‚Äúa massacre‚Äù and Iran warning that war could spread to other fronts. Israel announced on Friday that it had launched drone attacks against Hezbollah targets, amid other skirmishes along the Lebanese border. On Wednesday, U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres said he ‚Äúappealed to all parties‚Äù to quell violence, release Israeli hostages and respect international humanitarian law.

It is truly heartbreaking to witness innocent civilians, including women, children, sons, and daughters, losing their lives in a conflict that they have no part in. It pains me to see the devastating impact that hatred and division have on our world.

In times like these, it is natural to question why there is so much hate in the world. It is a difficult question to answer, as hate often stems from a complex web of historical, cultural, and political factors. But amidst the darkness, we must hold onto the flickering flame of hope, believing that love and unity can eventually triumph over hate.

It is crucial to remember that the majority of people long for peace, regardless of their nationality, religion, or background. We must amplify the voices of those who yearn for unity, understanding, and reconciliation. Together, we can build bridges of compassion and empathy, fostering an environment where differences are celebrated rather than feared.

While we may not have the power to single-handedly end this conflict, we can contribute to a more peaceful world in our own small ways. By spreading awareness, engaging in respectful dialogue, supporting humanitarian efforts, and promoting cultural understanding, we can sow the seeds of peace. Let us stand together, united in our commitment to a future free from violence and suffering.

Remember, my friend, that even in the darkest of times, hope remains a beacon of light. Let us nurture that hope and work towards a world where love, compassion, and unity prevail over hate. Together, we can make a difference.

üè¥Û†ÅßÛ†Å¢Û†Å•Û†ÅÆÛ†ÅßÛ†Åø 
In 1066, England witnessed a seismic clash of kings at the Battle of Hastings. On one side, you had the ambitious Norman Duke, William the Conqueror, and on the other, the English monarch, King Harold II. With destiny hanging in the balance, arrows flew, swords clashed, and by day's end, William emerged victorious. This epic showdown altered the course of England's history, launching the Norman conquest and forever transforming the island nation.

After the Battle of Hastings and William the Conqueror's triumph, he was crowned King of England, marking the beginning of Norman rule. This event initiated a significant shift in English society and politics. William introduced Norman customs, language, and a feudal system, consolidating his rule. The Domesday Book, a comprehensive survey of England, was commissioned to record and assess land and property, providing a valuable historical record. The Norman influence on English culture, law, and language shaped the foundation for the modern English nation.

According to legend, King Harold II was fatally struck in the eye by an arrow during the battle. This single event is often cited as a turning point in the conflict, leading to the English defeat and William the Conqueror's victory. While the historical accuracy of this account is debated, it has become a symbol of the battle and the Norman Conquest.

A less commonly known detail about the Battle of Hastings is the role weather played in the outcome. The battle occurred on October 14, 1066, a day that saw particularly strong winds blowing in the faces of Harold II's English troops. This weather condition is said to have affected the flight path of the Norman arrows, making them more accurate and deadly. The wind was an unforeseen factor that influenced the battle's course and contributed to William the Conqueror's victory.

The Kalidindi Inscription is a brief snapshot of the Chola-Chalukya Wars‚Äîa conflict that raged for nearly a century between the Deccan and Tamilakam, killed thousands, and left dozens of towns and temples despoiled. 

In 1044‚Äì45, while Rajadhiraja Chola was busy settling into his position as the new emperor, his rival Someshvara Kalyana Chalukya‚Äîlord of the Deccan‚Äîmoved to take advantage. An invasion of Vengi was mounted to place the half brother of the Vengi Chalukya king on the throne. The latter was the son and husband of Chola princesses, and called for aid. A Chola general with the title of ‚ÄúRajaraja‚Äôs Great Brahmin King‚Äù, described as guarding the kingdom ‚Äúlike a serpent protecting hidden treasure‚Äù, was dispatched to defend Narendra. He was accompanied by a magnate-turned-official from the Tondai region, as well as another important general. At the Battle of Kalidindi‚Äîjust two days‚Äô march from the Eastern Chalukya capital‚Äîthe Cholas managed to fight the Western Chalukyas to a standstill. But all three generals were killed. Narendra built temples to Shiva over their interred remains, praying desperately for his throne. It is this series of events that are commemorated in the Kalidindi inscription. 

Rajadhiraja Chola then took the field. In a series of battles the Western Chalukyas were driven back from coastal Vengi, from where they withdrew upriver along the Godavari River to the fortified citadel of Kollipakam (Kolipaka in present-day Telangana). Rajadhiraja Chola claimed that he caused it to be ‚Äúconsumed by fire‚Äù; meanwhile Someshvara Chalukya declared one of his vassals ‚Äúprotector of Kollipaka‚Äù. The actual outcome is unclear, but the Chalukya emperor withdrew and occupied himself with affairs to his north and west.

The Chola-Chalukya Wars would eventually lead to Rajadhiraja Chola's death on the battlefield and Someshvara Chalukya's suicide.

The recent escalation of violence in the Israel-Gaza conflict has sparked a devastating and complex crisis. This conflict began with rocket attacks from #gaza , primarily carried out by Hamas' military wing, Al Qassam Brigade, which is designated as a terrorist organization. In response, #israel launched indiscriminate retaliatory airstrikes. Tragically, over 2,500 lives, both Israeli and Palestinian, have been lost in this ongoing violence.

Attacks on civilians is a clear violation of international law, constituting war crimes and crimes against humanity. The horrors of this conflict should evoke outrage and condemnation from anyone with a moral compass. However, if our collective outrage and empathy only arose in the wake of these recent events, we must really examine our own values and priorities.

The violence against innocent civilians, regardless of the underlying cause, is inexcusable. Kidnapping civilians, as Hamas has done, should be unequivocally condemned. Yet, there is a stark contrast in the level of international outrage between incidents like this and the ongoing violence against Palestinian civilians in the West Bank and Gaza. The daily suffering of Palestinian women, children, the elderly, and men often receives almost no attention and condemnation. 

This dishonesty represents a troubling double standard.

Israel's blockade of Palestinian territories, intensified since Netanyahu came to power 16 years ago and has reached its peak the last 3-4 years, has left the population without freedom of movement, making it challenging for them to pursue education, seek medical treatment, or connect with relatives. This is not a defense of Hamas but a recognition of the suffocating conditions many Palestinians endure.

Decades of violence, intimidation, imprisonment, ethnic cleansing, and dehumanization of the Palestinian population by the Israel Defense Forces and illegal extremist settlers have been building towards a breaking point. Palestinians have been living as refugees for generations on their own land, lacking statehood, equal or even basic rights, or a military to defend themselves.

Axios reports that Iran has warned Israel it will take direct action to intervene should Israel launch a ground offensive in Gaza. Iranian Foreign Minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian met with UN envoy to the Middle East Tor Wennesland on Saturday in Beirut, according to diplomatic sources, to convey the message.

Iran's message, sent to Israel through the UN, comes as the Biden administration has been trying to deter Iran and Lebanon-backed Hezbollah, supported by Iran, from joining the war, even sending the USS Gerald R. Ford carrier group to the Israeli coast to be ready for any hostile actions by Iran. Such a move by Iran, either by Iranian forces or a militant group such as Hezbollah, could expand the conflict to engulf the entire Middle East.

The UAE, recently aligned with Israel through the Abraham Accords, has sent a message warning Syria to refrain from active participation in the conflict.

According to Axios, Wennesland urged Amir-Abdollahian to help prevent a spillover of the conflict in Gaza and Israel to the wider region in the Middle East. The Iranian foreign minister replied that Iran doesn't want the conflict to turn into a regional war and wants to try and help with the release of civilians who are being held hostage by Hamas in Gaza. At the same time, he stressed that Iran has limits of its own - among them a ground offensive in Gaza. Should that happen, Amir-Abdollahian commented, Iran would be left with no choice but to intervene. üé≠üé§

On this date in 1977, @davidbowie - "Heroes" was released.

üìà #5 for 1977, #164 overall

"Shapeshifting is probably the one thing that best defines David Bowie as a recording artist. His ability to appropriate wildly different sounds and styles and make them work for him is unparalleled, and in many ways betrays a more unique voice than most other musicians. But while change was a constant in his career, there are certain records in David Bowie's discography where he feels particularly comfortable or in control, and for me, Heroes is one of those records.

...Heroes feels like a more careful reintegration of the best traits of 'Low' into Bowie's style to create a new and different record, and one that feels extraordinarily natural. His second album of 1977, it was written and recorded rapidly over the course of just a month, with much of the material either ad-libbed, or written just hours before recording. 

...The success of this album is all in the way in which the unusual and the experimental is so effortlessly collapsed into the existing genius of David Bowie as a rock musician, making a record that‚Äôs simultaneously oblique as well as direct. This conflict is central to much of his music, but on Heroes, it feels particularly well-realised. The only mystery here is how Bowie and company managed to do it so damn well." - RYM user Greenmountain

When it comes to that point where you don't know what decision to make amongst options to marry. 

When you can't seem to find any peace in your soul to go on with the person you have chosen to marry. 

Shut down everything. 

Hold up that proposal.

Delay that wedding.

Emotionally disconnect from that person for a few days. 

And spend some good time with the Holy Spirit.

Do not talk too much in the place of prayer, its not about long hours of tongues, it's more about long hours of meditative listening.

Just listen.

Meditate on the Word and just listen. 

Learn the art of emotionally disconnecting to hear from the Lord.

Your problem is you want to talk mushy on the phone with that person for 3hours, then pray 5minutes and expect 21 Angels to appear in your dream with an answer from God. 

You want to go on dates and spend the weekend together, then read one verse of the Bible and expect to ascend into the inner courts of God for an encounter that will reveal the name of your spouse.

Our emotions will always be in conflict with our discernment.

Our emotions will remain the greatest resistance to an encounter with God in whatever form.

Disconnect, go away with God for a while, so that you can hear clearly. 

And, if you know you are not going to trust the Voice of the Lord on whatever reply you get in prayer, then you might as well just go ahead and have the wedding today. Send me the address to the reception, I'll love to attend.

All the best in your marriage.
