If you‚Äôre using social media to try and stay on top of what‚Äôs happening in Gaza and Israel right now, you should know that Elon Musk‚Äôs recent changes to Twitter have left the  platform awash in inflammatory inaccurate content about the conflict.

Changes like removing ways to report inaccurate content on the platform, rolling out paid verification that makes verification meaningless while algorithmically prioritizing content from paid users, and a monetization scheme that creates a financial incentive for posting engaging fake content has left Twitter not just unusable, but actively dangerous. 

We‚Äôve seen clips from video games being posted to Twitter purporting to show footage from the ground, stills taken from film sets purporting to show people ‚Äúfaking‚Äù injuries on the ground, a faked White House press release falsely claiming the Biden admin is releasing billions of dollars in aid to Israel and much much more, all amplified (not to mention potentially monetized!) by people with verified blue checks on the platform. 

It‚Äôs dangerous! Twitter has always had its problems, but it was once the best platform for following on the ground updates of ongoing situations and now it‚Äôs a marketplace for inflammatory garbage. It‚Äôs actively shaping the public perception of what‚Äôs happening in the conflict. 
The health, well being, and safety of our people is linked to the health well being and safety of our digital platforms.

I‚Äôve personally never seen anything like it. We are simply not prepared for how bad this is. We are simply not prepared for how much worse this could get.

We did a frustrating deep dive into all of this on the podcast There Are No Girls on the Internet. Major shout out to @shayan86bbc for doing amazing work verifying and debunking content on Twitter.

This is Rawand. I photographed her as she paddled for a wave in Gaza nearly 12 years ago. I kept in contact with her since then as she continued her studies, graduated from university, married and became a mother. The sense of isolation for Palestinians living in the Gaza Strip permeates every aspect of their lives. Barely anyone goes in or out since 2007, when both Israel and Egypt imposed a blockade after Hamas took full control of the enclave and abolished elections, along with any political opposition. Since Hamas‚Äô brutal attack that killed hundreds of Israeli civilians a week ago and the Israeli military response that flattened entire city blocks and killed hundreds of Palestinian civilians, I wrote to check on her, feeling heavy with worry and guilt for my complete powerlessness to help her. She told me her home was completely destroyed and she was lucky to have escaped it just in time. ‚ÄúPray for us‚Äù she said. Since then there‚Äôs barely been any electricity in Gaza, the IDF has ordered the evacuation of over a million people from the area where she lived, and I don‚Äôt know where she is now. I hope she‚Äôs safe, and that she‚Äôll have a chance to return and rebuild her home one day. I hope Kholoud (seen on the second photo here) is also safe and that time and hardship didn‚Äôt make a dent in her clever, fierce, and deeply kind character. I hope enough people on both sides of this conflict choose to reject extremism and dehumanisation and that this bloody week will mark the beginning of the end of this war no one can ever win. Israelis deserve to live without fear. Palestinians deserve to live without fear.

A historic handshake between two old adversaries - Israeli Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin and Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO) leader, Yasser Arafat - created a rare moment of hope for an end to the Israel-Palestinian conflict.

In September 1993, after weeks of secret negotiations, an interim peace agreement was signed on the White House lawn in front of US President Bill Clinton.

Two years later, Rabin was assassinated at a peace rally in Tel Aviv by a nationalist Jewish extremist opposed to the peace agreement. The murder sent shockwaves across Israel and dignitaries from around the world came to Rabin's funeral, a sign of the esteem in which he was held. #HistoryVille

As demonstrations condemning the violence in the Middle East continue to grow across the globe, we have connected with & listened to the concerns of our local communities who feel impacted by these international events.

We realize violence & large-scale demonstrations happening globally can instill a variety of emotions in Calgarians, leaving some feeling fearful.

In an effort to ensure all Calgarians feel safe in our city, today our officers proactively increased patrols near local places of worship & other areas of significance. We also setup our Mobile Command Vehicle downtown to ensure our officers are prepared to initiate a response to potential incidents.
 
At this time, there is no direct threat to the public in Calgary & we continue to work with other law enforcement agencies, community leaders & local groups in our city to monitor the situation.

It is standard practice for police to monitor all major, planned events & demonstrations, manage public safety, keep the peace & respond to any calls for service accordingly.

So far, there have been no incidents reported in Calgary in relation to the conflict in the Middle East.

We police behaviour, not beliefs. Hate-motivated crimes of any kind have no place in our community & we will not tolerate behaviour contrary to the law that is associated with hate speech or harassment.
 
We encourage anyone who is planning an event or a demonstration to review the information on our website: calgarypolice.ca/protesting.

We are committed to working with groups who want to organize an event that provides a safe & peaceful opportunity for demonstrators to exercise their lawful rights. Our objective is to work with all parties to ensure public & officer safety & to maintain orderly conduct and peace.

Isabella, Duchess of Lorraine and Queen of Naples (1400-1453). She was the daughter of Charles II, Duke of Lorraine and his wife Margarete of the Palatinate.

She was born in France as the eldest daughter, her younger sister Catherine was born in (1407). She also had two brothers but these died young. After the death of her brothers, it was made apparent in (1410) that Isabella would be the successor of her father in Lorraine and was therefore given a careful education. 

On 24 October (1419), Isabella married Ren√© of Anjou. He was the son of King Louis II of Naples and thus a heir to the throne. The couple had ten children, three of whom survived childhood and early adolescence. 

Isabella inherited the duchy of Lorraine from her father upon his death in (1431), and ruled jointly with her husband as her co-ruler. In (1435), she also became queen of Naples when her husband succeeded his father as king. During her first time as queen, Isabella acted as her husband's general governor and regent, as he had been imprisoned after a conflict with Isabella's cousin regarding her inheritance rights to Lorraine. She remained in this position until her husband's release and arrival in Naples (1438).

In the 1440s, Isabella returned to Lorraine, where she continued to administer the duchy. In (1445), however, she appointed her son John to be her governor general in Lorraine, and retired to her manor Launay in Saumur.

As a person, Isabella has been described as witty and brave, with the ability to be careful and make hard decisions in difficult circumstances. In addition to that, she was praised for her beauty and sharp mind. She is also said to have been the one who introduced one of her ladies-in-waiting, Agn√®s Sorel, to King Charles VII of France. Agn√®s soon afterwards became the king's influential mistress and is considered the first officially recognized royal mistress of a French king. 

Isabella died on 28 February (1453), aged 53 and was buried in Cath√©drale Saint-Maurice d'Angers in western France. #royalhistory #isabellaoflorraine #duchessoflorraine #houseofardennesmetz #frenchroyals #historicalroyals

Sharing content during active conflict is a sensitive matter that requires careful consideration.ü§ù Here are some guidelines to consider:

üí≠ Consider the Audience: Think about your audience and their sensitivities. Avoid sharing graphic content with individuals who may be triggered or distressed by it, such as children, those with PTSD, or people who have experienced trauma.

üîç Verify the Source and Authenticity: Ensure that the content is from a credible source, and verify its authenticity to prevent spreading misinformation or propaganda. Use reputable news outlets, verified social media accounts, or fact-checking websites to confirm the information.

üìö Provide Background: When sharing distressing content, provide details to help your audience understand what they're seeing. Explain the situation, location, and any relevant background information. This can help prevent misunderstandings and misinformation.

‚ö†Ô∏è Content Warnings: Use content warnings or trigger warnings before sharing graphic images or videos. This gives people the choice to engage with the content or not, and it shows respect for their emotional well-being.

üö´ Respect Privacy and Dignity: Avoid sharing content that invades the privacy of individuals or portrays them in a demeaning or dehumanizing way. Respect the dignity of those affected by the conflict.

ü§î Evaluate the Relevance: Consider whether sharing the content serves a meaningful purpose, such as raising awareness, advocating for a cause, or documenting important events. Avoid sharing content for the sake of sensationalism.

‚ÄúCan I just get a minute when you‚Äôre not throwing another problem in my face?‚Äù a senior doctor (Prakash Belawadi) asks his nurse (Balaji Gauri) at the Bombay General Hospital in the second season of Mumbai Diaries. She responds with ‚Äì ‚Äúyou can get a samosa, an ice cream, maybe even a cola, but you can‚Äôt get a minute without a new problem cropping up.‚Äù

After all, it‚Äôs the nature of a government hospital ‚Äì where resources are finite, but an ailment is always around to be treated. The first season of the Nikkhil Advani show was a medical drama ‚Äì a group of young doctors grappling with the eternal push-and-pull with the administration and protocol that gets in the way of saving lives in the ER, with the aftermath of the 26/11 Mumbai terror attacks.

As a medical drama, Mumbai Diaries: 26/11 was just about there, ticking most of the boxes of the genre, led by a maverick doctor, Kaushik Oberoi (Mohit Raina) whose method often skirts the lines of brilliant instinct and reckless daredevilry. Surrounded by superiors who bat for his ways, rookies (Natasha Bharadwaj, Satyajeet Dubey and Mrunmayee Deshpande) who look up to him, Dr. Oberoi is emboldened to listen to his gut rather than following protocol to treat patients. It lent itself to a superb conflict in the first season, when the hotshot doctor tries to revive a gravely injured terrorist who shot a cop, after the cop‚Äôs condition goes beyond medical help. There‚Äôs resistance from within the hospital staff, cops, and even the slain cop‚Äôs spouse.

The second season begins a few months after the events of the first season, in the midst of a torrential downpour the city is known for. Even though the show‚Äôs events lie somewhere in June 2009, it uses the events of the 2005 floods that ravaged the city, as the springboard for events in the second season.

Breathing and the Metal Element

Autumn can be the time to lay the foundations of our health for the coming year. It is time to still our hearts and minds and to gather and collect our energy. Metal is the phase of energy represented by late autumn. It is the time when leaves fall to the earth and a time of refinement for the individual. Just as trees are drawing in and letting go of their leaves, it is time for us to let go of what we have been carrying around all year, but may no longer need.

In the animal kingdom, it is the time to store only what is needed for winter and let go of what can be discarded. Autumn is a time to reflect on the cycle of the seasons, and to be thankful for an abundant harvest. Consciously breathing helps us to release tension and to be grateful for the simple act of breathing. Breathing consciously each day can have an extraordinary effect on our health and create peace of mind through autumn and winter.

A person who exhibits the metal energy in balance is someone with integrity who is balanced and fair. They do not want disorder and conflict and prefer structure and stability. A metal person is typically an expert in their field and seeks perfection. They think logically and acting with methodical efficiency. When the metal element is out of balance, a person can be selfish, dishonest, lack integrity, and be sneaky.

Statement in response to misreporting on the rally for Palestine: 

After the protest in support of Palestine on Friday, October 13, the Fox8 news channel falsely reported that WHOA organized the action and agitated protestors to seize the street. 

This occurred after one of our comrades explicitly explained to Fox8 reporters that WHOA did not organize the action, and after Fox8 spoke to an actual organizer of the event for around 20 minutes.

We can only conclude that this story was purposefully misreported. 

The actual organizers of the event were Muslims for a Better NC and GRS, so we are told.

All WHOA did was elevate the action on our social media in solidarity with the organizers to bolster numbers and note our stance on the conflict. Some comrades attended the event, but in no way did WHOA play a leading role. 

We aren‚Äôt entirely certain why Fox8 misreported this story, but we can only imagine they did so to obfuscate the reality that the Muslim community broadly opposes Israel‚Äôs actions against the Palestinian people. For mainstream news outlets such as Fox8, it is more convenient to suppose that a pre-identified radical organization independently takes a strong stance on the conflict between Israel and Hamas, when, in reality, much of the community actually does oppose Israel‚Äôs actions. 

Story in question (which calls us the ‚ÄúWorking-class and Houseless Organization Alliance"): https://myfox8.com/news/north-carolina/greensboro/pro-palestine-protest-held-in-greensboro-as-conflict-between-israel-hamas-escalates/

It‚Äôs been a dreadful week. Humanity must prevail.

We should embrace the power of informed opinions and exercise caution when discussing topics about which we lack knowledge. It's crucial to educate ourselves before sharing our viewpoints. Keep in mind that when we do express our thoughts, it's often through our unique perspectives. 

We all have the capacity to learn more about the ongoing conflict, especially for those of us in Western countries like the US AND UK, where our understanding may be shaped by mainstream western media narratives.

If you're keen on expanding your knowledge about this conflict, here are some book recommendations for you. Several of these are available on the hoopla app.

1. Uncivil rites by Steven Salaita
2. Freedom is a constant struggle by Angela y. Davis
3. Ten myths about israel by Ilan Pappe
4. The ethnic cleansing of palestine Ilan Pappe
5. The hundred years' war on Palestine by Rashid i. Khalidi
6. The 1936-39 revolt in palestine by Ghassan Kanafani
7. Israel's occupation by Neve Gordon
8. Justice for some by Noura Erakat
9. The palestine communist party 1919-1948 by M≈´s√° Budayrƒ´
10. Against the loveless world BY Susan Abulhawa is one of my favourite books of all time. changed my life, it‚Äôs an absolute masterpiece.
11. Mornings in Jenin BY Susan Abulhawa changed my whole perspective and i'd recommend it to everyone
13. Decolonizing Israel. Liberating Palestine by Jeff Halper
14. Orientalism by Edward Said
on palestine by Noam chomsky + Ilan papp√©

16. Image & reality of the Israel Palestine conflict" by Norman Finkelstein

‚ÄúWe mourn the tragic deaths of those killed in Palestine and Israel,‚Äù says Rick Cober Bauman, MCC Canada Executive Director. ‚ÄúWe lament this new wave of conflict and invite churches to pray for the many families whose loved ones have been killed in both Israel and Palestine.‚Äù

MCC is planning an emergency relief response with existing partners, focused on the immediate humanitarian needs in the Gaza Strip, given the vulnerability of the population and lack of resources available to families. The initial response will include distributing food and bedding. In the longer-term, MCC also plans to respond with trauma healing support and housing reconstruction.

Currently, no food, fuel or medicine can enter Gaza, as the last remaining access from Egypt was shut down after airstrikes hit the border crossing. Communities in Gaza were already experiencing extreme hardships due to previous Israeli military operations and the 16-year blockade, which restricts the movement of people and goods in and out of Gaza. 

Sarah Funkhouser and Seth Malone, MCC staff, say that reports from MCC partners in Gaza are deeply troubling. 

‚ÄúOur partners in Gaza are reporting a lot of bombing, more than they‚Äôve ever seen before,‚Äù says Malone. ‚ÄúBut we‚Äôre also hearing from partners that it‚Äôs not safe to be inside when buildings are being targeted like this. The situation is dire for civilians here, electricity is cut off, water is cut off, food is cut off.‚Äù

The building of one of MCC‚Äôs partners in the Gaza Strip, the Near East Council of Churches (NECC), was severely damaged by airstrikes, including its medicine storage facility and classrooms where job skills training took place. Many homes of partner staff have also been destroyed by bombing. Despite this devastation, partners are committed to helping those in need.

MCC is also urging world leaders to encourage immediate de-escalation and hold all parties to the same standard of international law regarding the protection of civilians and respect for human rights. We invite others to do the same. Links in bio.

Photo: One of the buildings used by the Near East Council of Churches, an MCC partner in the Gaza Strip.

Blinken met with King Abdullah of Jordan, who rules over a country with a large Palestinian population and has a vested interest in their status, and also with Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, who runs the Palestinian Authority, which controls the West Bank. ‚Å†
‚Å†
King Abdullah warned Blinken of ‚Äúany attempt to forcibly displace the Palestinians from all the Palestinian Territories or to cause their internal displacement, calling for preventing a spillover of the crisis into neighboring countries and the exacerbation of the refugee issue,‚Äù Jordan‚Äôs government said in a statement. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Abdullah also stressed the need to open humanitarian corridors for medical aid and relief into Gaza while protecting civilians and working to end the escalation of the conflict. He appealed for international agencies to be allowed to work unhindered. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Blinken discussed with the king the efforts to release all the hostages the Hamas militants seized, as well as efforts to prevent the conflict from widening, State Department spokesperson Matthew Miller said. ‚Å†

Vivian Silver, 74, a member of Kibbutz Be‚Äôeri, near the northern end of Gaza, was still missing on Monday night and presumed to have been taken hostage. Ms. Silver, a native of Winnipeg, Manitoba, was among the leaders of Women Wage Peace, a large grass-roots movement founded in the aftermath of the Gaza War of 2014 to promote a political resolution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

She served for many years on the board of directors of B‚ÄôTselem, an Israeli human rights organization that said Israel was an apartheid state. She made visits to the occupied territories to express solidarity with Palestinians and volunteered with an organization that drove sick Palestinians from Gaza into Israel for medical treatment. She is the executive director of the Negev Institute for Strategies of Peace and Development and co-founded the Arab Jewish Center for Equality Empowerment and Cooperation.

One of her sons, Yonatan Zeigen, told the Israeli newspaper Ha‚Äôaretz that he last communicated with her on Saturday morning, when she said she was hiding in a closet in a safe room on the kibbutz. They started to text rather than speak as the sound of shooting got closer, but there was no communication from her after 11:07 a.m., he said.

Ms. Silver is ‚Äúprobably worried sick about the Palestinian contacts in her phone, a friend wrote on Facebook. ‚ÄúShe probably thinks of the danger they will now face for being seen as collaborators with the enemy.‚Äù

That peace-oriented Israelis were among Hamas‚Äôs targets has fueled further resentment of the Netanyahu government, which was caught by surprise on Saturday when Hamas fighters from the Gaza Strip streamed into Israel on Saturday, meeting little resistance.

Israel faced an unprecedented and cruel attack by Hamas, which began on a Jewish Holy Day. Over 1,300 Israelis have lost their lives, and more than 2,900 are injured. Over 150 were taken into captivity - mainly civilians. Many elderly, kids, and babies are held hostage in Gaza and now the current threat is to execute them. 
Israel is defending itself, but the conflict continues, with no end in sight.

In response, Abraham has opened its doors to host evacuee families free of charge.
We gladly host these guests and try to take care of all their needs: supportive care, employment for children, food, and more. Civil organizations started to help us and we are grateful for any contribution that comes to help.
Because we see that the situation will go on, we are starting to collect donations for hosting and caring for the families of the evacuees in Abraham. 

Your donations are essential to help those affected by the ongoing conflict.
Your support will offer help during these challenging times.

I don‚Äôt support regimes or organizations lead by men and their narcissistic endless pursuit of power. 

I don‚Äôt support regimes or organizations influenced and manipulated by international power houses led by men and their narcissistic endless hunger for power. 

I care about people, civilians like you and me who are caught in this war of egos, this power aided by propaganda, this crossfire of power trips. 

No community should be dehumanized. 

No death, rape, body desecration of civilians is justifiable. 

No children or elder should be left vulnerable to massacre, to be the victims of a war they didn‚Äôt cause. 

No patriarchal, macho power trip against the bodies of women and girls is justifiable. 

Terrorism is condemnable. 

Powerhouses led by unscrupulous, evil, greedy men meddled in this conflict. Outsiders are also responsible for the terror. They have the blood of innocents on their hands. 

No one should be undergoing the immense trauma caused by occupation and ceaseless oppression. 

The horror of colonization is something no human should ever have to go through and yet ‚Ä¶ 

Mi gente, don‚Äôt let the  propaganda of either antisemitism or islamophobia crawl on you. 

Hateful rhetoric is planted there for a purpose and it‚Äôs easy to cave into it mindlessly. 

Those that are part of targeted diasporas know that a large community shouldn‚Äôt be punished or hated by the actions of a few. 

I have been elevating knowledgeable voices in my stories and will continue to do so. 

Palestinian and Jewish friends, I see you. I am grieving with you. 

As @valariekaur says, we need to refuse to surrender our humanity and the humanity of others. 

Numbness and dehumanization justify anything.

Humanization and love wouldn‚Äôt.

Please take a moment to read this thoughtful message from Anyupa Butcher
Posted @withregram ‚Ä¢ @napangarti ‚ú® today, I‚Äôm writing yes. Here in the NT we are only coming out of 15 years of living under the NT intervention! The damage that is left our communities in is horrible. Everything our previous generations fought for was completely torn to shreds. Our communities and what felt like our personal lives being controlled, for 15 years. I‚Äôve lost many family members who have passed away from preventable deaths, we still have third world diseases in remote central Australia! You can only understand if you have lived it, like I have. Living on the basics card and under these punitive laws etc It impacted me as a First Nations woman and as a mother to my kids. I grew up in between the remote communities of Papunya and Yuendumu and here in Alice Springs, born and raised on Arrernte Country. I‚Äôve spent time in cities too. Seeing the disparity between these places is unjustifiable. You have to live it to understand. I have so many personal experiences seeing and experiencing the racism, poverty and discrimination my people are faced with. Something has to change. I only started campaigning on the referendum one week ago when I made my decision. I‚Äôve had an inner conflict for a while. But, I feel clear about my feelings, and I believe a voice to parliament is what is best for me and my kids. I‚Äôll always have love and understanding to those who have different views. But I don‚Äôt believe the voice will divide us. The division already exists within the constitution, making laws specifically for us. Like the NT intervention. The voice will allow us to have a say on those laws so we can be empowered to better our communities. For me it‚Äôs a matter of urgency that something changes & I really hope you consider this when voting today, because so many are living in extreme circumstances. How can we protect country or be our greatest selves when there‚Äôs a pandemic of chronic illness amongst our families & many are living in third world conditions. This voice to parliament could help & that‚Äôs a hope I‚Äôll vote yes for üåª Let‚Äôs be kind and supportive today

Around 600 Telangana workers in Israel face a dilemma ‚Äì return to India or continue working amidst the conflict with Hamas.

One worker, Rajesh Medichalmala Rajesh, is staying to support his daughter's dream of becoming a doctor. "I have to keep my daughter's dream alive. I cannot panic and return to India. I have to earn enough for my daughter. I will work here as long as I can stay," he said.

Despite safety concerns, many workers choose to remain in Israel to sustain their livelihoods. An association called the Telangana Association in Israel advises workers not to rush back to India despite evacuation efforts under 'Operation Ajay.'

Responding to tragedies shouldn‚Äôt be performative and I have laboured for the last week to find the words, to be able to articulate myself hopefully thoughtfully and clearly, which is why I am sharing this now. I needed the time to be able to navigate and process the tragedy of last Saturday as well as what is continuing to unfold.

As a woman, a mother, a Canadian, the wife of an Iranian-Canadian, a dual citizen of Iran myself, I share this not only aware of the current events unfolding but of what may come if more countries, Iran, are drawn into the conflict. That would likely mean the possible loss of life of people who are my family. For now, that‚Äôs not where we are but it lives in the heads of myself, my family and the Iranian community outside of and inside of Iran.

I am obviously not an expert, I write this as an individual, as the creator of this space and community. My ask is that your comments in response are attempt to equally as thoughtfully as what I have tried to share here.

Sarah

The children sat in the back seat of the car as their parents spoke in code.

Mya Guarnieri Jaradat and her ex-husband, Mohamed Jaradat, spoke in snippets of English and Arabic. Sensing something was amiss as they headed to the beach, their 7-year-old daughter asked what was wrong.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a war in Israel,‚Äù Mya said.

‚ÄúWho are they fighting?‚Äù their daughter asked.

Mya is an American Israeli who grew up in Gainesville, Fla. Mohamed is Palestinian. For the last nine years, they have lived in Florida.

They were quiet for a moment as the little girl waited.

Finally, it was Mohamed who spoke: ‚ÄúThe Palestinians.‚Äù

The day before, fighters from the Palestinian militant group Hamas had executed a surprise cross-border attack by land, sea and air ‚Äî the deadliest attack on Israel in 50 years.

More than 1,300 Israelis and 1,900 Palestinians ‚Äî including many children ‚Äî have been killed since Hamas fighters attacked southern Israel on Saturday and the Netanyahu government declared war in response. In Israel, Hamas gunmen killed more than 250 civilians at a music festival and took others hostage. In the Gaza Strip, residential neighborhoods were flattened beyond recognition by Israeli bombardment.

The carnage continues with no end in sight.

The conflict in the Middle East has shaped Mya and Mohamed‚Äôs lives ‚Äî and love ‚Äî since they met in the West Bank more than a decade before. And now, on a sunny weekend in October, that conflict had once again landed squarely on their family.

As Mya and Mohamed struggled to process this latest war, the fault lines of their relationship reappeared. Similar tense scenes have been playing out for Jewish-Palestinian couples across the U.S., where news of the war is omnipresent on computer, cellphone and television screens and in the pages of newspapers.

To be continued üëá

For Abood Okal and his family, the nights are the worst ‚Äî and each night is worse than the last.

When it grows dark, the bombing in Gaza intensifies. Sometimes there is an explosion every few minutes, close enough to make the house shake. In the morning, they feel fortunate to be alive.

Okal‚Äôs family is among a group of about 500 Americans caught in Gaza, according to a U.S. official who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Following Saturday‚Äôs unprecedented attacks by Hamas, Israel has massed troops near the border with Gaza and pounded the territory with airstrikes.

‚ÄúThis is probably the most traumatic experience of my life,‚Äù he said. He is frightened for his wife, his child, his parents, his siblings, his extended family. He has experienced periods of violent conflict in Gaza before, but nothing like this. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never seen things on this scale,‚Äù Okal said.

üíîThis was just 8 days ago.  7 days ago, we left Cairo in the morning, and brutal attacks were launched just a few hundred miles away.  The heartbreaking acts of violence and terrorism committed by Hamas have weighed heavily on us all this week, and have prevented me from posting this until now.
 
üíïAnd yet ‚Ä¶ there was so much joy in this experience, and I DO want to document that. Desmond Tutu said, ‚ÄúHope is being able to see that there is light despite all of the darkness,‚Äù and I agree.
 
üôèüèºThis trip ‚Ä¶ hiking in Switzerland, Oktoberfest in Germany, and seeing the pyramids and Sphinx in Egypt ‚Ä¶ was one for which I am EXTREMELY grateful.

üôèüèºüôèüèºGrateful to have seen these incredible places, full of beauty, culture, and history.

üôèüèºüôèüèºGrateful to have an incredible travel (and life) partner.  There‚Äôs truly no one in the world I‚Äôd rather do life with.

üôèüèºüôèüèºGrateful to have the financial, time, and life freedom to be able to do trips like this whenever I want.

üôèüèºüôèüèºGrateful for the physical health to be able to travel like this (3 cities, 3 hotels, 9 trains, and 29 hours of plane flights all in 8 days requires resilience!).

üôèüèºüôèüèºGrateful for being happy to come back to a home and life I love.
 
ü§∑üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è(To be clear, I don‚Äôt claim to be educated enough to know ‚Äúthe answer‚Äù to the entire Israel/Palestine situation, and I don‚Äôt like to comment on ‚Äúpolitical‚Äù things on The Lyons‚Äô Share.  But I know for sure that beheadings and brutal attacks on innocent citizens are abhorrent, are not political, and are condemned here.  We can all be anti-Hamas and anti-terrorism without taking a stand on the longstanding conflict).

Los nuevos medios t√©cnicos empleados tanto en la captaci√≥n como en la difusi√≥n de las fotograf√≠as durante la contienda en Espa√±a tuvieron un papel de suma importancia en la difusi√≥n del conflicto a nivel internacional. Esta singularidad se debe en buena medida al uso de herramientas, que si bien hab√≠an aparecido a√±os atr√°s, aqu√≠ se perfeccionaron y combinaron dando pie a perspectivas y procedimientos de trabajo novedosos. 

La finalidad de esta tecnolog√≠a era atender los requerimientos de la creciente maquinaria medi√°tica en varios √°mbitos: agilizar los procesos de producci√≥n de noticias, facilitar la inmersi√≥n del reportero en el lugar de los hechos, privilegiar el protagonismo informativo de las im√°genes y alcanzar una cobertura mundial de los acontecimientos. Los avances fueron numerosos: reducci√≥n del tama√±o de las c√°maras, simplificando y agilizando su manejo; desarrollo de objetivos m√°s luminosos y de diversas distancias focales, fabricaci√≥n de emulsiones fotogr√°ficas m√°s sensibles que permitieran captar situaciones en condiciones de luz adversas y la creaci√≥n de pel√≠culas de grano fino para su duplicaci√≥n.

As news began to seep out of Israel of an unprecedented massacre of civilians by Hamas, it was immediately clear to European diplomats that this could herald a new major conflict in the Middle East, writes Naomi O'Learly. 

At a time when many observant Jewish people around the world had not yet heard the news because their phones were turned off for the Sabbath, calls began pinging between the capitals of the 27 European Union countries on Saturday morning to co-ordinate a response.

To anyone familiar with the conflict it was a given that Israel would respond to the attack with massive air strikes on Gaza. By the time people were having their breakfast in Ireland on Saturday the bombing had already begun.

Israeli air strikes flattened the Al-Sousi Mosque and a high-rise residential building in densely-populated Gaza city on early Saturday, video suggests. M√©decins Sans Fronti√®res reported that a hit on a hospital had killed an ambulance driver and a nurse. Large numbers of wounded people began arriving at hospitals. Unable to leave due to the narrow strip‚Äôs sealed borders, frightened residents began emptying out supermarkets to stock up on food.

‚ÄúWe are at war,‚Äù Israeli prime minister Binyamin Netanyahu declared. He announced a mass call-up of army reservists ‚Äúto fight back on a scale and intensity that the enemy has so far not experienced‚Äù. It was an indication of a potential ground war.

In the aftermath, either due to a distorted rumour or a deliberate attempt to discredit those seen as ‚Äúsoft on Palestine‚Äù, Ireland, Luxembourg, and Denmark were named in an incorrect Israeli media report as having refused to describe Hamas as a terror group. They all publicly denied it ‚Äì but not before the damaging claim went viral.

In the spring of 1949, foreign ministers from Canada, the United States, and Western Europe met in Washington D.C. to sign the North Atlantic Treaty. Many thought the treaty, which effectively created the military alliance known as NATO, would not last, with The Washington Post writing that the signing ceremony was ‚Äúmore spectacular than the act itself.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
One person who did not share this sentiment was Norman Angell, a British journalist and politician who believed it was only a matter of time before humanity would say goodbye to war forever. In his 1909 book The Great Illusion, Angell argued that developed countries were becoming so economically dependent on each other that the costs of international conflict far outweighed its gains.‚Å†
‚Å†
Sadly, his prediction was proven wrong by the outbreak of World War I five years later, and again by that of World War II in 1939. Angell hoped the North Atlantic Treaty, replacing previous attempts at unification like Woodrow Wilson‚Äôs League of Nations, would finally create the stabilized world order he had spent the better part of his career writing about. But did it?‚Å†
‚Å†

During my stay in Israel and visiting Gaza, I had the opportunity to visit the Dome of the Rock and the Temple Mount. It became abundantly clear that this spot holds unparalleled significance for three of the major modern-day religions: Christianity, Islam, and Judaism. The historical and religious importance of this place, coupled with its contested nature, serves as a poignant reminder of the complexities of the Middle East conflict.

The coexistence of these three religions in such a confined space has historically been a source of tension. While each faith has its own deep-rooted connection to the site, it also brings the potential for clashes and disputes. It became evident that achieving lasting peace in the Middle East would be an intricate challenge, given the sacredness of the Dome of the Rock and the Temple Mount to all three faiths.

Yet, my visit also shed light on another troubling aspect of the region. I could not ignore the harsh reality of apartheid-like conditions prevailing in Gaza, where the Palestinian people are enduring immense suffering. Witnessing this situation prompted me to delve into extensive research to better understand the region and its multifaceted conflicts.

As I delved deeper into my studies and conversations with people from various backgrounds, I couldn't help but draw parallels between the plight of the Palestinian people and that of so many Black communities around the world. The shared experiences of discrimination, marginalization, and the struggle for basic human rights resonated across these different contexts.

My time in Israel and Gaza served as a catalyst for my ongoing exploration of the Middle East's complexities and the enduring quest for peace. The importance of the Dome of the Rock and the Temple Mount to three major religions underscores the intricacies of the region's conflicts. Simultaneously, the alarming conditions in Gaza highlighted the urgent need for a just and equitable resolution to the Palestinian-Israeli conflict. It is crucial to recognize that, despite geographical and cultural differences, the struggle for equality and justice unites people facing oppression around the world. #freepalestine

Reflecting on this past week, my aspiration remains the same: 100% global peace for all 7.8 billion souls.

In the ongoing conflict in the Middle East, the Israeli military reported on a Saturday that it had detected a "significant movement" to the south of Palestinian civilian areas. This followed a directive from Israeli authorities the previous day, instructing residents of Gaza City to evacuate. Israel's Prime Minister also pledged further retaliation in response to what he referred to as Hamas' recent rampage.

On the international front, U.S. President Joe Biden confirmed that consultations were underway with regional governments to address the escalating humanitarian crisis in Gaza. Trapped Palestinians in the region have been enduring a severe power blackout and shortages of essential supplies like food and water, exacerbated by intense Israeli airstrikes.

The root of this recent escalation lies in a deadly attack by Hamas a week earlier, where its fighters targeted Israelis, resulting in the tragic deaths of 1,300 individuals, primarily civilians. Furthermore, they seized numerous hostages during the incident.

In response, Israel has imposed a total blockade on the Hamas-controlled Gaza Strip, which is home to approximately 2.3 million Palestinians. The region has faced unprecedented aerial bombardment from the Israeli military, causing significant casualties. Gaza authorities have reported the loss of around 1,900 lives as a result of this recent conflict.

This situation continues to evolve, and international efforts are being made to address the escalating tensions and the dire humanitarian situation in the region.

For the past week, news from Israel and Gaza has been distressing.‚Å£
‚Å£
When news events like conflict, natural disasters, pandemics and other tragedies reach our screens, it can cause a lot of anxiety and even a sense of hopelessness.‚Å£
‚Å£
For people living with dementia, the constant stream of images on the news may cause additional worry and feel overwhelming ‚Äì perhaps because it brings back personal memories of their own distressing experiences, such as living through previous times of conflict or tragedy.‚Å£
‚Å£
We can‚Äôt make the news go away, but we do have some tips for dealing with it.‚Å£
‚Å£
The 24-hour news cycle can make it difficult to switch off, so try to limit how much you read, watch or listen to.‚Å£
‚Å£
Take care of your mental health. If you or someone you support is struggling with stress or anxiety that is affecting your ability to function properly, or you are feeling very low, then contact your GP for help. Or call our Dementia support line if you are lonely or afraid and need a chat.‚Å£
‚Å£
Understand a person may be 'time-shifting; and their experience may be that they are living at an earlier time in their life. They may become disorientated and confused about time and place. Try to accept the reality of the person with dementia, listen to them, and try to understand their past.‚Å£
‚Å£
Tap the link in our bio to read the advice in full. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Alzheimer‚Äôs Society is here for you, whatever your question. We can answer queries about all aspects of dementia and offer advice and support for all associated challenges, including dealing with anxiety and being overwhelmed. Call us on 0333 150 3456

I made this Star of David for my wife a few years ago. Today, I watched her take it off when she left the house because she is scared. We wanted to go to the synagogue, but instead we live-streamed it because she was scared. They had armed security there because they are scared. 

I am no oppressed minority, My beliefs are secular, and I am as privileged as the next white guy. This is the first time I have experienced a fear of simply existing. Do not give me any sympathy, I do not need it. I just want to say that for many, a jewish existence is one that is full of fear right now. 

I am not here to tell you what to believe, or think. My perspective is one from privilege just seeing a tiny window of something else through my wife, my family. 

I will not tell any Jew, or Palestinian what they should think or do, But I will tell others who are in a place similar to me (white, housed, tax paying thus Israel supporting like it or not, civilian who has never experienced war, leftist, socialist, feminist, now I am just virtue signaling like the rest‚Ä¶) that if you know someone who is attached to this conflict, give them love, give them space, and muster up as much empathy as you can. While I do not have any close Palestinian friends that confide in me, I am sure many of their experiences (here in the states) are similar, an existence shadowed with fear. 

If you want a statement from me about the bigger issues, I don‚Äôt really have one and I am not nearly educated enough to debate or pretend I actually understand anything at all. I guess just go up to a mirror, and pull back your lips, you have bones sticking out through your damn skin. We are all just apes, and we can‚Äôt control the world as much as we would like to, but we can be the best that each of us can be, and I do believe that love is a very large piece of peace.

The Israeli‚ÄìLebanese conflict, or the South Lebanon conflict was a series of clashes involving Israel, Lebanon, Syria,and the Palestinians. The Palestinian Liberation Organization rebel group was known to recruit Palestinian refugees in Lebanon who had been expelled or fled after the creation of Israel in 1948. In the 1970s, the PLO established a base in Southern Lebanon, resulting in an increase of internal, cross-border violence and tensions regarding the refugee population demographic changes. Israel's 1978 invasion of Lebanon pushed the PLO north of the Litani River, but the rebels continued their campaign against Israel. Israel formed an alliance with Lebanese Christian militias and forcibly expelled the PLO and established a pro Israel puppet state called the free Lebanon state. In 1985, Hezbollah, a Lebanese Shia Muslim militant movement sponsored by Iran, called for an end to the Israeli occupation of Lebanese territory which they eventually did in 2000s

Members of the Jewish community in Chicago gathered near Belmont Harbor on Thursday to honor Palestinians and Israelis killed in the ongoing conflict.

The mourner‚Äôs Kaddish, a Jewish prayer typically spoken during the mourning period after the death of a loved one, was recited by members affiliated with the group IfNotNow, a national Jewish organization that advocates for the end of the Israeli government‚Äôs presence in Gaza and the West Bank.

‚ÄúWe are here to grieve for the innocent Israelis, including children, who were killed by Hamas,‚Äù Elie Katzman-Jacobson of IfNotNow told those gathered. ‚ÄúWe are here to grieve for the innocent Palestinians, including children, who have been killed by the Israeli Defense Force.‚Äù

Candles were lit in memory of those killed, and attendees sang prayers for those still missing and for peace in the region. Organizers also read part of a poem by Palestinian American poet Suheir Hammad.

Hamas‚Äô surprise attack on Saturday killed more than 1,300 people in Israel, including 222 soldiers ‚Äî a toll unseen in Israel for decades ‚Äî and the ensuing Israeli bombardment has killed more than 1,400 people in Gaza, according to authorities on both sides. Israel says roughly 1,500 Hamas militants were killed inside Israel, and that hundreds of the dead in Gaza are Hamas members.

Gaza‚Äôs interior ministry on Thursday said that an Israeli airstrike on a residential building in the densely populated Jabaliya refugee camp in northern Gaza has killed at least 45 people and wounded dozens more.

Eli Newell, who is also with IfNotNow, said people should remember that every person killed had their own story and were someone‚Äôs loved one.

‚ÄúChildren, teachers, doctors, artists, neighbors and so much more,‚Äù Newell said. ‚ÄúAll lives lost too soon.‚Äù

Newell added that this isn‚Äôt the first time that blood has been spilled in the region. He said the only way to end the conflict is for the Israeli government to come up with a solution that works for all parties.

Conflict can be tough but handled well it can increase connection and build your relationship. 

How you communicate is important. 

üëâ Start the conversation with a soft tone. 

üëâ Affirm your commitment to the relationship and desire to address problems in a way that is good for both of you. 

üëâ Avoid blaming, accusing, or name calling. 

üëâ Humility can soften your partner.  Be the first to express where you believe you may be wrong.

These and many other communication approaches can help but you‚Äôve likely seen that once one of you is hurt, pissed off, or scared that even the most perfect communication has little effect. 

Learning to manage and regulate your own emotions is the key to improving the conflict in your relationship. 

Without staying emotionally grounded you won‚Äôt be able to communicate well and will struggle to receive what your partner says. 

If you‚Äôd like help in this area check out the link in my bio. 

You‚Äôll learn the science behind how to stay emotionally grounded in the midst of conflict and why on a neurological level this is crucial for navigating conflict well.

A bitter row is brewing within the family of the late renowned businessman and architect Peter Kamya who owned Simbamanyo Estates Ltd and Afrique Suites in Mutungo.

Kamya passed away in December last year, but since then, his family has been entangled in a major dispute over his estate.

At the heart of the conflict are the late Kamya‚Äôs widow, Dr. Margaret Muganwa, and the children that the tycoon left behind.

Dr Muganwa is a sister to former Deputy Prime Minister Henry Muganwa Kajura.

Although at the time of his passing, it was reported by the widow that Kamya left behind only five children, it has now been established that the correct number is 17.

It is also understood that Dr Muganwa is contesting the paternity of 12 of the 17 children and has since demanded DNA tests to be carried out.

The ongoing family feud over the properties, however, recently took a turn after the widow, Dr Muganwa was granted a certificate of no objection, in effect giving her total control over the Kamya estate.

A source tells this reporter that tension has since spiked as the family prepares for the final rites at Kamya's ancestral home, where the issue of the property allocation is expected to take center stage.

‚ÄúThe 17 children, who had previously supported the widow, are now resolute in their pursuit of a fair and equitable distribution of their father‚Äôs estate,‚Äù the source said.

The children however, according to the source, have vowed to fight on and secure their due inheritance.

Some of the children include; Martin Muwonge, Dorothy Namatovu, Eugene Kasozi, Anne Caroline Nansamba, Michael Semakula, Agnes Nasozi, Immaculate Nabukeera, Philomena Nabukenya, Bart Mulinde, Alfred Nsamba, Petrin Nalubega, Ferdinand Mpuga, Cyril Eva Kuteesa, and Helen Mirembe

Two students who wished to remain anonymous, a sophomore and a second-year master‚Äôs international student from Palestine, also spoke. ‚ÄúI know it can be really hard in the classroom, when you feel like you are outnumbered,‚Äù Namakkal said. ‚Äú... One of the reasons we decided we needed to do this immediately was so you could see the other faces in this room and say, ‚ÄôActually, we‚Äôre not alone.‚Äô‚Äù

"Alakazam's Lament"

After his many versions disappeared, Alakazam sat exhausted. "What's the matter? You seem weary," the sorcerer's student said. "In manifesting realities with consciousness, one encounters in existence the multitudes of other consciousnesses manifesting within reality. Not all of these are positive," the sorcerer said.
As the student pondered this, he noticed energies pouring out of and into Alakazam. The light coming in was soft and warm, however the energies coming out of the sorcerer looked like severed tendrils. The student looked upon his mentor and realized the life of a sorcerer was not an easy one. There was both pain and reward .

"I am tired!" The sorcerer yelled. "The path of a sorcerer is to acquire knowledge, so we can manifest harmony. Never use what you've learned to harm others!  I am tired of seeing all the fighting and discord in this existence!" The apprentice stood dazed, never seeing their teacher so frustrated. "It begins on the individual level. You must learn to love yourself before you love others. There's so much hate in this world between friends, communities, nations. The reason we acquire knowledge is to understand each other and achieve harmony for all souls. I've been a peaceful warrior for so long, had so much of my energy lost to preventing conflict, and am tired." 

The sorcerer's apprentice approached him, and beautifully understanding that his teacher was both powerful, & yet still wholly human, the student approached his teacher with tears in his eyes. "Master, you are not alone," said the student. "I am with you, and don't ever forget the light will always connect to the greater light." Acknowledging his student, the teacher stood wiping his tears of sadness away. Placing his hands onto the apprentice's shoulders, the man that was a sorcerer looked into his students eyes, the Great & The Terrible & the Human Being. "You have listened to everything I've said and brought me hope. I feel now, because you believe in pursuing knowledge & harmony this world can be healed. Thank you my dear friend."

I've been thinking a lot about what's happening right now in the Middle East. I have been thinking about the years I spent in rooms at the UN listening to people talk about this conflict, the maps, the plans, the agreements, the sincere pleas of regular people and the bad faith pronouncements of politicians, and I've thought about the stories my father told me growing up of picking grapefruits as a young man in the 1960s in the orchards of Kibbutz Magen, and the story I read this week of a man fleeing his home in Gaza with the family's pet goldfish stashed in a plastic jar of water. The reine claude plums are still in the markets, and I liked the look of these three on the plate, so I painted them. It's still wet, so please excuse the shine.

Editors' Note:
Corrections have been made to this article surrounding terminology used when describing the Israeli Defense Forces‚Äô bombings of Palestinian civilians, including in Gaza, as well as the removal of a UO Fraternity and Sorority Life organization that was previously mentioned in the report. The organization was not involved with the publication of the article. The Emerald also mistakenly quoted Alpha Epsilon Pi‚Äôs national chapter as opposed to the UO chapter.

The Emerald is working to cover updates on the conflict as it relates to the University of Oregon and to clarify language used in previous reports. This is a sensitive topic and it deserves to be covered delicately. We are keeping the updated article on our website for transparency and as a reminder to hold ourselves accountable moving forward.
We intended our initial article to be a breaking news report on the vigil on Oct. 9 held at UO by Oregon Hillel, as well as a gathering of initial reactions to the attack in Israel.

In doing so, we made several mistakes. We rushed out an article that relied heavily on social media statements and failed to bring in an array of student voices and perspectives. Instead, we covered more background on statements made by government officials unaffiliated with the Oregon Hillel vigil, as well as an overly brief background on a conflict with a long history behind it. We should have interviewed a wider variety of voices before the publishing of this article.

As an independent student media organization, our job is not to take political stances on specific issues, but instead to report the facts as they happen ‚Äî fairly and accurately. Part of that means providing a thorough look at all sides of an issue. We regret that we failed to do this, and we are working to provide a more comprehensive perspective from all points of view.

The Emerald regrets these errors.

#RayverCruz saw #JulieAnneSanJose as a strong foundation of hope when they were locked down in Israel following the militant Hamas forces attack on the country on Oct. 8.¬†

In an interview on Fast Talk with Boy Abunda, the couple shared their experience of having been caught in the crossfire of the Israel-Hamas war along with GMA artist Boobay after they went to the country for their trio concert "Luv Trip Na, Laff Trip Pa," which was supposed to be held at the Smolarz Auditorium at the Tel Aviv University.

They have since arrived safely to the Philippines on Oct. 9.

According to Julie, they had absolutely no idea about the conflict that was happening in the country, "Nung pagkalapag pa lang namin ng Israel, nilibot na namin. Sobrang excited kami na mag-ikot and to visit different places."

"Ang bilis ng pangyayari," both Julie and Rayver said as they recalled the time when the bombing started on the morning of Oct. 7.

"Hindi alam [ng mga managers namin] kung paano nila kami gigisingin in a way na sabihin samin na kailangan na naming bumangon kasi may gyera na," Rayver recounted.

The two of them explained that the place they were staying at had a bomb shelter, and a siren would sound off to signal them that they had to rush to the bunker within one minute as the bomb would drop within 90 seconds.

Rayver shared that there was an instance where the lights of the building they were in began to shake because of how close the third bombing was to them.

When asked if the actor ever thought about proposing to Julie during those life-threatening moments, Rayver said that he was already one with her "mind, body, and soul."

"Nung time ng pangatlong pagsabog at pagpasok, para sa akin, everything happens for a reason. Siya lang ang nakakaalam, yung sa Itaas," he said.

"Para sa akin, yung glimmer of hope, yung lakas ng loob ko, nanggagaling kay Julie. So iniisip ko, may rason kung bakit si Julie magkasama kami sa Holy Land. And then for me, mind, body, and soul, kasal na ako sa kanya," he continued.

Do you fight fair in your relationship? 

These are just a few tips to consider next time you get in conflict with your partner. 

ü™© Don‚Äôt bring up the past! 
It might be tempting to bring up all the issues of the past but don‚Äôt do it. It‚Äôs overwhelming and you lose sight of what you were fighting about in the first place. 

ü™©Take a break. 
Learning how to take a break to self-regulate is helpful to strip a fight from escalating. Coming back to the topic is important when you feel you can talk through it.

ü™© Don‚Äôt hit below the belt. 
Don‚Äôt be mean or say things you wish you didn‚Äôt say later on. Words hurt and it doesn‚Äôt help your relationship thrive in or out of a fight. 

ü™© Don‚Äôt fight to win. 
Fighting to win or be right gets you nowhere and disconnects you from your partner. Be partners not enemies.

Biden made it a point to say the laws of war should be observed and Israel needn‚Äôt unnecessarily target civilians. He also urged Netanyahu via phone call to take pains to minimize Palestinian casualties.

Yet, Israeli forces continue to target the press and innocent civilians including over 600 children. The Palestinian death toll is now at 2,000. 

This morning on NPR, reporters on the ground in Israel stated there were no signs that Israel forces would relent anytime soon.

Ben Rhodes was a national security official in President Barack Obama's administration posted on X: ‚ÄúThe decisions being made now are going to impact millions of lives, reverberate for generations, and risk all kinds of escalation. The U.S. should have learned from 9/11 the profound cost of being guided by anger and fear. I hope that is what we are telling the Israeli government.‚Äù

During a news conference in Qatar today, Secretary of State Antony Blinken said: ‚ÄúWe continue to discuss with Israel the importance of taking every possible precaution to avoid harming civilians. We recognize that many Palestinian families in Gaza are suffering through no fault of their own and that Palestinian civilians have lost their lives.‚Äù

Current and former U.S. officials have been trying to deescalate but it may be too late especially as the U.S. vehemently showed unequivocal solidarity with Israel early into the conflict and provided them the world‚Äôs largest warship among other resources. A former U.S. official stated: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre trying to convince them [the Israelis], but emotions are running high.‚Äù

If the Israeli government continues this way, what moral high ground will they stand on?

Nakba.. 
75 years of persecution of the Palestinian people by Jews- Israeli settlers since 1948. 
According to United Nation, The Nakba, which means ‚Äúcatastrophe‚Äù in Arabic, refers to the mass displacement and dispossession of Palestinians during the 1948 Arab-Israeli war. Before the Nakba, Palestine was a multi-ethnic and multi-cultural society. However, the conflict between Arabs and Jews intensified in the 1930s with the increase of Jewish immigration, driven by persecution in Europe, and with the Zionist movement aiming to establish a Jewish state in Palestine.

In November 1947, the UN General Assembly passed a resolution partitioning Palestine into two states, one Jewish and one Arab, with Jerusalem under a UN administration. The Arab world rejected the plan, arguing that it was unfair and violated the UN Charter. Jewish militias launched attacks against Palestinian villages, forcing thousands to flee. The situation escalated into a full-blown war in 1948, with the end of the British Mandate and the departure of British forces, the declaration of independence of the State of Israel and the entry of neighbouring Arab armies. The newly established Israeli forces launched a major offensive. The result of the war was the permanent displacement of more than half of the Palestinian population.

As early as December 1948, the UN General Assembly called for refugee return, property restitution and compensation (resolution 194 (II)). However, 75 years later, despite countless UN resolutions, the rights of the Palestinians continue to be denied. According to the UN Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees (UNRWA) more than 5 million Palestine refugees are scattered throughout the Middle East.  Today, Palestinians continue to be dispossessed and displaced by Israeli settlements, evictions, land confiscation and home demolitions. The Nakba anniversary is a reminder not only of those tragic events of 1948, but of the ongoing injustice suffered by the Palestinians. The Nakba had a profound impact on the Palestinian people, who lost their homes, their land, and their way of life. It remains a deeply traumatic event in their collective memory.

On October 7th, the militant group Hamas, based in Palestine, initiated an assault on Israeli territory, resulting in the loss of hundreds of lives and the abduction of over 100 individuals. On October 13th, Palestinians from around the world came together to participate in the "International Day of Action for Palestine." In New York City, thousands of Palestinians were joined by various groups, including Americans for Palestine and Jews for Palestine, among others.

To Palestinians, this attack was perceived as a defensive response to what they regard as 'atrocities from Israel' during these seven and a half decades. An elderly Palestinian shared, 'For those of you unfamiliar with our history, it is a very confusing situation. Organizations representing a Livonia family and other Palestinian Americans "trapped" in the Gaza Strip are suing in the Eastern District of Michigan to expedite efforts to ensure their safe return to the U.S.

"I'm terrified; they haven't ever been in this situation before," said Yahya Alarayshi, whose parents, Zakaria Alarayshi and Laila Alarayshi, were supposed to return to Metro Detroit on Oct. 20. "They are scared; they're not safe."

A lawsuit was filed Friday by the Alarayshis, U.S. citizens of Palestinian ethnicity, who reside in Livonia, the Arab-American Anti-Discrimination Committee and Arab Civil Rights League.

The lawsuit said the Alarayshis "are currently trapped abroad in the Gaza Strip in an active war zone where they are under imminent threat of death or serious bodily injury," adding that the legal action was not an attempt to to interfere with the armed conflict in Israel and Palestine, but rather to "compel a governmental agenc(ies) to initiate evacuation efforts and secure the safety and well-being of its citizens."

On Saturday, evacuation orders from Israeli forces renewed calls for Gaza residents to stream south from their homes in north region of the territory, while Hamas urged civilians to stay in their homes, one week following their surprise attacks on Israel.

At a press conference Saturday afternoon outside the courthouse in downtown Detroit, Yahya Alarayshi said his parents remain stationed in place. He said they tried to reach the Egyptian border as State Department officials had instructed, but they were told it's closed and provided no information for evacuation.

Egyptian officials said the country's Rafah border crossing with Gaza would open Saturday for the first time in days to allow foreigners out. One official said both Israel and Palestinian militant groups had agreed to facilitate the departures, but by Saturday evening there had been no movement.

I'm still struggling with my thoughts on the current state of the world...I am strongly against extreme human conflict of any kind. I continually call myself a world peace advocate.

Having been fortunate enough to travel to Jerusalem, Germany, and Japan (epicenters of extreme conflict)- I've continued to try and understand how anyone could kill someone else for any reason, let alone for a feeling, thought, or belief. 

This first photo is in a market in Israel and the last is in Hiroshima, Japan. This middle is filled with the amazing memories, people, time, and experiences I had while traveling in Israel. Along with one of my visits to the Anne Franke House in Amsterdam. 

I'm Jewish. I don't believe in God. I think every person deserves to be heard. I think we all have a right to freedom over our own bodies. And I think extreme conflict for any reason is a waste of human energy. 

I side with humanity and I pray for a day when humans focus on helping each other daily because at the end of the day... each other and the planet we live on is truly all we have. And it is precisely why I wake up every day trying to simply help others. I also pray for the safety of everyone I know and everyone I don't currently who are living in extreme conflict.

Park Seo-bo‚Äôs predominantly monochrome experiments with linear abstraction helped define Dansaekhwa, an essential movement within Korean modernism. Park is perhaps best known for his ‚ÄúEcriture‚Äù series, which exemplifies the artist‚Äôs focus on material and process; in order to create precise, cumulative canvases, he penciled marks into still-wet painted surfaces, then layered Korean hanji paper overtop. Park graduated from Seoul‚Äôs Hongik University in 1954, when South Korea was still reeling from military conflict with North Korea. He has exhibited widely over the years, in galleries from Seoul and Busan to Tokyo, Los Angeles, New York, and Beijing. His work belongs in the collections of the Museum of Modern Art, the Art Institute of Chicago, the Museum of Contemporary Art in Tokyo, and the Seoul Museum of Art, among many other institutions. His precise, minimalist practice filters Western notions of abstraction through the lenses of Korean calligraphy and Buddhist and Taoist philosophy.

I wrote the poem "The Side of Peace" in 2009. It pains me to re-read it and realize that Israel/Palestine is experiencing the exact same situation now.

I‚Äôve marched in Gaza rallies
And sung for Arab crowds
Though some of my relations
Think I should not be allowed.
I‚Äôm asked why do I do it?
Or if I‚Äôm scared at the very least;
The only answer that I have,
Is I‚Äôm on the side of Peace.

I always say I‚Äôm Jewish,
It‚Äôs part of who I am.
So is speaking out 
For human rights as best I can.
This conflict is immoral
I want it all to cease
And that is why I take a stand
On the side of Peace.

When innocent civilians
Are killed day after day
By military massacres
I have the right to say
Collective punishment is wrong 
As the death tolls increase.
The only way to save lives
Is on the side of Peace.

Unlike so many others
I can‚Äôt support a nation
When it‚Äôs so horrific towards 
Part of the population
Yes, the leaders are not innocent
But the children are, indeed 
So are all the others who
Are on the side of Peace.

It‚Äôs easy to be silent
Or toe the party line
Complicity is for cowards
Who are part of the crime.
I will never be accused
Of groveling on my knees
I stand with my conscience
On the side of Peace.
--

#onthisdayinhistory Martin Luther King Jr. won the Nobel Peace Prize for his nonviolent advocacy for an end to segregation in the United States on October 14, 1964. The Nobel Peace Prize is an award created by Norwegian arms manufacturer and philanthropist Alfred Nobel. The award goes to any individual or organization that advances peace and diplomacy through their actions. MLK was the youngest recipient at the time, being only 35 years old. MLK was awarded the prize after the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom and the passage of the 1964 Civil Rights Act. In his acceptance speech, MLK said the following:

‚ÄúI accept the Nobel Prize for Peace at a moment when 22 million Negroes of the United States of America are engaged in a creative battle to end the long night of racial injustice. I accept this award on behalf of a civil rights movement which is moving with determination and a majestic scorn for risk and danger to establish a reign of freedom and a rule of justice.‚Äù 

King wondered why the civil rights movement was not given the prize since there was not a peace on all sides of the conflict. King concluded that ‚Äúthat nonviolence is the answer to the crucial political and moral question of our time ‚Äî the need for man to overcome oppression and violence without resorting to violence and oppression‚Ä¶ Civilization and violence are antithetical concepts. Negroes of the United States, following the people of India, have demonstrated that nonviolence is not sterile passivity, but a powerful moral force which makes for social transformation. Sooner or later all the people of the world will have to discover a way to live together in peace, and thereby transform this pending cosmic elegy into a creative psalm of brotherhood.‚Äù

King concluded his speech by saying that ‚Äúpeace is more precious than diamonds or silver or gold.‚Äù King donated the $54,123 he received in prize money and donated it to other parts of the Civil Rights Movement. #mlk #civilrights #nobelpeaceprize #civilrights

Nearly eight in 10 Americans fear the war that erupted this week between Israel and Hamas will lead to a broader war in the Middle East, according to the latest PBS NewsHour/NPR/Marist poll.

With seven in 10 U.S. adults saying they are closely following what is happening, the anxiety about further escalation is shared across political affiliation, geography, gender, race, income, education and age. A third of U.S. adults said they were ‚Äúvery concerned‚Äù about wider violence in the region, according to this latest poll.

Hamas militants made an unprecedented incursion into Israel during the early hours of Oct. 7, firing thousands of rockets and sending fighters past Israel‚Äôs blockade of Gaza to launch  deadly attacks on several communities and take scores of hostages. The combined death toll from both the surprise assault as well as Israel‚Äôs bombardment of Gaza in response has risen to at least 2,800 lives.

On Friday, Israel ordered 1.1 million Palestinians in northern Gaza to evacuate in 24 hours, despite a warning from the United Nations that the short deadline could be disastrous. The evacuation orders come ahead of Israel‚Äôs anticipated ground invasion against Hamas. In recent days, Israel cut off food, water and electricity to the besieged area, where more than 2 million predominantly Palestinian residents have been ruled since 2007 by Hamas, which the United States has designated as a terrorist group.

The violent conflict has inflamed long-running animosity between Israel and its neighbors, with Turkey calling that nation‚Äôs response ‚Äúa massacre‚Äù and Iran warning that war could spread to other fronts. Israel announced on Friday that it had launched drone attacks against Hezbollah targets, amid other skirmishes along the Lebanese border. On Wednesday, U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres said he ‚Äúappealed to all parties‚Äù to quell violence, release Israeli hostages and respect international humanitarian law.

‚ÄúI choose to focus on ‚Äòconflict transformation‚Äô rather than the more traditional term‚Äôconflict resolution‚Äô. To me, the latter suggests going back to a previous state of affairs, and has a connotation that there may be a winner or a looser. How will this disagreement be resolved? Whose solution will be selected as the ‚Äò better‚Äô one? In contrast, I choose to focus on ‚Äò conflict transformation‚Äô suggesting that by creatively navigating the conversational landscape of differences and disagreements, we have the opportunity to create something new, at minimum we learn more about eachother than before. Ideally, we may find new possibilities that had not even been considered before. Conflict transformation is about creating deeper understandings. It requires perspective- taking. As a result, it enables greater connection weather or not there is agreement.‚Äù

Man‚Äôs inhumanity towards man. It‚Äôs a story that has repeated itself endlessly, since the beginning of humankind‚Ä¶ whether it‚Äôs out of hatred, greed, competition for land and resources, or retribution, there‚Äôs no end to the various ways people will savage one another. And isn‚Äôt it the innocent people caught up in the slaughter that suffer the most! It‚Äôs horrifying. It makes me feel depressed, angry, helpless. 

The Ukrainian War and the Israeli-Hamas War are prime examples that are attracting the most attention now. 

But war is ever present in our societies. 
Here‚Äôs a list of the 41 ongoing wars from around the globe‚Ä¶

Do not turn your eyes and hearts away from the children of Gaza. 

Do not allow yourself to lose your humanity in this moment. To all the people unfollowing me this week I send you love and healing. 

I pray that we can forge a world where our shared humanity is the foundation and the lives of our global siblings and all of our children are equal and valued.
 
Calls for peace are empty and hollow without calls for justice. The root of violence is dehumanization, oppression and injustice.
 
We need healing on a scale much larger than we may think is possible. A one sided narrative only creates further disinformation and division.
 
So much of the narrative that we see unfold in the mainstream media and on social media is very one sided with so many whataboutisms, lack of understanding and nuance of the historical context of this crises. 

Empty blanket statements help no one and only serve to uphold the paradigm of wyt supremacy and structures and systems of oppression. I have been sharing a lot about this in my stories. 

Adopting a decolonial mindset is pivotal when it comes to understanding the root causes of oppression. 

None of us are truly free until all of us are free. None of us can be well until all of us have access to being well. The Palestinians have not had this for 75 years. 

I pray for a just and peaceful resolution to this conflict. I pray for collective liberation ‚ù§Ô∏è.

Human Rights Watch exposes Israel's alleged use of white phosphorus in Gaza and Lebanon, violating international law by endangering densely populated regions. White phosphorus, though not a chemical weapon, inflicts severe burns and organ damage, impacting humans and infrastructure. Despite past instances, its use persists, sparking concerns over civilian safety and adherence to international conventions, prompting urgent calls for intervention and accountability.

@humanrightswatch

On July 1, 1863, the three days long Battle of Gettysburg began. One of the conflict's first casualties was Lancaster resident Major General John F. Reynolds. He was shot through the neck by a Confederate sharpshooter while leading his men into battle. Reynolds died instantly from the wound, becoming the highest-ranking soldier on either side killed at Gettysburg.
.
However, Reynolds' story doesn't end with his death. Shortly before the battle, Reynolds (a Protestant) had secretly engaged his longtime Catholic sweetheart, Catherine Mary Hewitt. After a discreet courtship, they planned to marry upon his return from Gettysburg.
.
This is where things get interesting. Some believe Kate's grief was so deep that Reynolds' spirit never found peace. As such, his ghost wanders the streets between the Fulton and his family home, looking to meet his fianc√© just as he had promised he would more than 150 years ago. So if you feel a chill while walking near 42-44 West King Street and notice a tall, handsome, anachronistic dressed man, there's a good chance you just saw Reynolds' ghost.
.
Click the link in the profile to read the whole story.
.
.
.

Hi friends,

Since many of you have asked, my first Sunday at Central Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) will be October 29th.  There are in-person worship services at 8:30 AM and 11 AM, and you can always catch the 11 AM on Facebook Live. 

I'm looking forward to starting a new chapter in a familiar place, and hope to see those of you who'd like to join us!

--The window in the picture is a focal point of Central's sanctuary. I've always loved the way it expresses a theology of presence and solidarity ("...Became Flesh and Dwells Among Us.") The panel in the lower right has been on my mind during this season of violence, war, and global conflict.--

And of course, for those of you wanting to know more, Central is MANY things:

1. A Founding Congregation of the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ)

2. A Justice-Seeking Open and Affirming Congregation. (See the Central welcome statement: www.centralchristianlex.org/who-we-are)
3. A Place dedicated to beautiful worship and community.

4. A Place where the table is open to all. And All means all.

To learn more: www.centralchristianlex.org/

His Highness Prince Faisal Alfarhan received Secretary of State Anthony Blinken to discuss in Riyadh . During the meeting, the Saudi Foreign Minister reiterated that the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia strongly rejects any calls for the forced displacement of the Palestinian people from Gaza and condemns targeting civilians in any form. The minister stressed that the Kingdom calls for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza and its surrounding areas, lifting the siege on Gaza as per the international law, and ensuring the entry of urgent humanitarian aid, such as food and medicine.
He emphasized the importance of taking swift collective action to end the ongoing cycle of violence and all forms of military escalation against civilians to prevent a humanitarian catastrophe.
Prince Faisal emphasized the urgent need to prevent more innocent civilians from falling victim to the ongoing cycle of violence. He stressed that Israel must abide by international humanitarian law and avoid any actions that contradict it, as such actions will only worsen the current crisis and increase the suffering in the region.
He also underlined that dialogue is the only way to achieve a just and comprehensive political solution to the conflict. He called on the international community to fulfill its responsibility in stopping the violence and promoting the peace process as per the resolutions of the UN Security Council, the UN General Assembly, and the Arab Peace Initiative.

The news cycle has been heavy this past week with natural disasters and conflict affecting children in so many places. 

While children in Australia are physically removed from these devastating circumstances, it can be difficult to control what they see and hear and the feelings it evokes. It's important to speak with your child about what's happening globally, not only about the facts (in an age-appropriate way) but also about what's being done to help children and families caught in crises. 

Check the link in bio for more resources on talking to children and young people about emergencies and how to keep your young person safe online.

Every child deserves to feel safe and protected, no matter where they are.
