Beach reading before the rain starts.
.
In the spring of 1742, a Shawnee war party journeyed hundreds of miles to the Eastern Shore of the Chesapeake Bay to recruit allies for a war against the English colonists. The once-mighty but diminished Nanticokes, whose great-grandparents had greeted Captain John Smith with arrows, invited several other tribes‚Äîthe Choptank, Assateague, Pocomoke, and Askecksy Indians‚Äîto meet at a place called Wimbesocom. A daring plan was proposed: With the help of hundreds of fierce northern warriors, the Eastern Shore tribes would carry out a surprise raid against their English neighbors and slaughter everyone-men, women, and children.
.
Meanwhile, French forces would land on the coast and help them drive the white man off the peninsula, splitting the English colonies.
.
If they succeeded, they would remake the destiny of North America.
.
If they failed, they might lose their lands forever.
.
1742 traces the history of the Nanticoke Indians and other Eastern Shore tribes from their first contact with English colonists through decades of bloody conflict and bitter concessions, revealing a simmering resistance which boiled over during what historian C. A. Weslager called "the most important single event in Indian history on the Delmarva Peninsula.‚Äù
.
.
.
#unchartedlancaster #rehoboth #rehobothbeach #1742 #beachread

Just finished reading this incredible book, and I could not recommend it enough! I‚Äôve never posted a book review before, but this one was worth it. Read my brief thoughts below ‚¨áÔ∏è

"Son of Hamas" by Mosab Hassan Yousef is an incredibly powerful and eye-opening memoir that provides a unique perspective on the Middle East conflict. Yousef skillfully personifies the complexities of the region, offering readers an inside look at the workings and beliefs of the Hamas organization. His journey from being born into a culture of terrorism to actively pursuing peace is nothing short of extraordinary. This book is a must-read for anyone seeking a deeper understanding of the ongoing complexities surrounding Palestine and Israel, as it sheds light on the human experiences behind the headlines.

Mosab Hassan Yousef's narrative is not just a captivating story but a testament to the potential for change and reconciliation in even the most entrenched conflicts. His firsthand account provides invaluable insights, making "Son of Hamas" a compelling and enlightening read.

#sonofhamas #politicalbooks #standwithisrael #prayforisrael #prayforpeace

I can‚Äôt post normally as if our world isn‚Äôt in turmoil. We‚Äôre privileged to be safe at home, but my heart is in the east. I‚Äôm sick over the bloodshed of innocents, families destroyed by terrorism, and the vicious cycle of violence that continues on. 

In 2019, @dadavidcoe and i took this photo with the Ahava sculpture at the Israel Museum in Jerusalem. Ahava ◊ê◊î◊ë◊î means ‚Äòlove‚Äô in Hebrew, and that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm holding onto hardest, as I pray for those held hostage, for humanity, healing, and peace. 

I‚Äôm Jewish, and my best friend and sister of 20 years is Palestinian. Despite what headlines would have you believe, as usual, our feelings align and we are united. There is no debate that each human life is sacred, that Hamas is evil personified, that slaughter of civilians is monstrous, and that in wartime, nobody wins.  This is not the first time we will cry and commiserate over the suffering in Gaza, nor will it be the last. 
 
This century long conflict is being reduced to quick quips and hot takes, and I implore you to please, look beyond black-and-white propaganda to see the human suffering, the shades of grey. You can support Palestinian human rights while calling out the evil of Hamas. You can acknowledge Israel as the ancestral Jewish homeland while disagreeing with actions of its government. 

Violence only begets violence, and I feel so helpless. I‚Äôll light extra Shabbat candles tonight, for all who cannot, and for hope, which flickers faintly even in these dark times. 

 üïä

Neutrality is not an Option

Since the Israel-Palestine conflict has flared up, many on the broader Right have insisted that this is not their conflict. Apparently, we should remain indifferent to the ethnic cleansing and barbarity of the Israeli‚Äôs, the plight of the Palestinians is something to ignore.

Yet to avert your gaze from the scenes of the wounded children, dilapidated buildings and unmitigated terror which is ravaging Gaza, is to misunderstand what it means to be a nationalist. 

The Palestinians were in fact the first people to experience ‚ÄúThe Great Replacement‚Äù when Zionist settlers began to illegally immigrate to Palestine. From the late 19th century starting with the Ottomans and through the British Mandate, successive governments attempted to regulate and limit Jewish migration to Palestine but with no avail. 

Aside from their test run on population replacement with the Palestinians, Zionist Israel is practically an open portal to hell. Israeli scientists are responsible for the COVID vaccines (Pfizer & Moderna) while Israel is home to Teva Pharmaceuticals, the world‚Äôs largest producer of trans hormones, hormone blockers and medication. Israel is also one of the world‚Äôs largest manufacturers of weaponry and military technology which they sell to bloodthirsty Muslim nations like Azerbaijan who in turn ethnically cleanse multiple millennia old Christian populations like the Armenians of Artsakh. 

When the evidence comes into full view, American & European nationalists must not remain neutral, as the Israeli‚Äôs certainly don‚Äôt. When Israeli & Jewish NGO‚Äôs like Isra-AID or HIAS organize migrant caravans into the West, are they being neutral? 

When Israeli ‚Äúscience‚Äù and ‚Äúmedicine‚Äù warps the minds of our youth and deconstructs the fundamental underpinnings of humanity itself, are the Israeli‚Äôs acting as honest brokers?

When Israel & the Jewish diaspora petition our governments to wage wars which have erased Christianity from its historic home in the Levant, was that just an accident?

Enlightenment, in its simplest form, is about accepting reality as it is, without resistance. It‚Äôs about letting go of our preconceived notions, our judgments, our desires for how things should be. It‚Äôs about embracing the present moment, in all its beauty and imperfection.

Resistance creates conflict, tension, and suffering. It‚Äôs a barrier that keeps us from experiencing life fully, from seeing the truth clearly. When we resist what is, we create a divide between ourselves and reality. We become entangled in our thoughts, our fears, our illusions.

On the other hand, the absence of resistance brings peace, clarity, and freedom. It allows us to flow with life, rather than against it. It opens our eyes to the wonder of the present moment, to the wisdom inherent in each experience.

So, let‚Äôs strive for enlightenment. Let‚Äôs strive to let go of resistance, to accept what is. Let‚Äôs strive to live in the present, to embrace reality as it is. Because in the end, enlightenment is nothing more than the complete absence of resistance to what is.

Remember, the journey to enlightenment is not a destination, but a journey. It‚Äôs not about reaching a certain point, but about continuously growing, learning, and evolving. It‚Äôs about embracing humility, fostering empathy, and recognizing our interconnectedness. So, let‚Äôs embark on this journey, one step at a time, one breath at a time. Because in the end, we are not just individuals on separate paths, but parts of a larger whole, moving together towards enlightenment.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.

I recalled the history we learned of the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in August 1945, the only use of nuclear weapons in an armed conflict. So many people died, mostly innocent civilians, that their numbers are not even concise. The total number of deaths was likely more than 150,000 but may have been more than 200,000. We were taught that this was necessary to save lives, a strange calculus to use when discussing the use of asymmetrical weaponry that would go on to cause long-term health consequences to those within the radii of the bombed cities. Many more innocent people were injured and traumatized, their lives forever broken by bombs dropped upon them for a war they did not choose to wage. Nevertheless, the loss of their lives was viewed as a "necessary and less evil option" in the math of war.

We will never know what would have happened if the people in Hiroshima and Nagasaki would have been spared of such horrific destruction and trauma. Those days are forever sealed in our history. Those who died - innocent men, women, children - were intentionally denied their right to life by a cold calculation devoid of empathy because an emporer they did not choose allied their country with the Axis powers and waged war against enemies the innocent people also did not choose.

I will never support the intentional killings of any innocent civilians, no matter where they live or who their leaders are. As someone whose government often violates what they deem to be ethical values, I know that leaders of people are far too often more concerned about their own power and ego than what is ethical and right. I do not wish to be judged by the actions of leaders that do not align with my values. I think most people feel this way. Let the leaders meet in war rooms to fight with one another, and leave the rest of us out of it so that we can live our lives. 

I will always be on the side of the innocent. Always.

Labour utterly condemns Hamas‚Äôs appalling terrorist attacks on Israel that led to such brutal loss of life, including of British citizens.

We stand in solidarity with Israel in these dark hours and urge that all hostages should be released.

We fully support Israel‚Äôs right to defend itself, rescue hostages and protect its civilians.

As we have said from the beginning, that right must be exercised in line with international law, and civilians must be protected.

The situation in Gaza is heart-breaking. Both Israelis and Palestinians are suffering terribly because of Hamas‚Äôs actions. I am deeply saddened by the loss of innocent life in Gaza.

There must be a clear distinction between Hamas terrorists and the Palestinian people. 

It is vital that there is continued humanitarian access to Gaza, and continued supplies of food, water, electricity and medicines.

The Shadow Foreign Secretary David Lammy MP and Shadow Cabinet Minister for International Development Lisa Nandy MP are in touch with the UK government, the UN and NGOs to discuss the best way to protect civilians, including humanitarian corridors within Gaza. None of us want civilians to suffer.

We must not allow these tragic events to divide our communities. The Community Safety Trust and the police have reported a steep increase in antisemitic incidents in recent days, including abuse and assaults. Tell Mama has also reported a tripling of cases to their services within the last six days, including reports of Islamophobic threats, abuse and assaults.

We denounce hate crime in the strongest terms. We expect to see a robust response to all incidents of hate associated with the conflict, and call on government to support these groups and to play their part in preventing an escalation of tensions.

Locally I have been in close contact with our police and others. We are proud of our diverse communities and I know many people will be feeling deeply affected, or may even be directly affected, by these events.

Community and faith organisations across the country are playing their part in efforts to bring down tensions and in bringing people back together. I support those efforts.

In a long-standing conflict between Isreal and Palestine/Hamas , the elusive truth remains a casualty. For decades, these nations have engaged in relentless battles, marked by bombings, skirmishes, and unprovoked raids. Amid this chaos, the battle for truth intensifies as media outlets and governments manipulate news and reports, leaving the public struggling to discern fact from fiction.

Astonishingly, Egypt had issued warnings to Israel and the US three days prior, raising questions about the effectiveness of intelligence networks.

Adding to the intrigue, the international stage witnesses a curious contrast. While the US and UK boldly flex their military might with battleships in the sea, their response to the Ukrainian-Russian conflict pales in comparison. This stark disparity raises eyebrows and prompts a crucial question: Why the difference in approach?
People are not divided by religion. They are divided by how they choose to solve problems.

By the late 1880s, less than twenty-five bison remained in Yellowstone National Park. Currently, the bison population in the park is between about 4,800 to 5,000. This August, the National Park Service released a 137 page draft of their Environmental Impact Statement for how to manage the shaggy creature within the park boundaries.

Feeling ‚Äòtriggered‚Äô will have us behaving in some less than ideal ways if we aren‚Äôt careful‚Ä¶

Conflict, and difficult conversations in general, have the tendency to get really emotionally charged and can often result in feeling triggered, overwhelmed, and scared. 

In these moments, many of us feel so desperate to get our point across‚Ä¶ to feel seen, heard, and understood‚Ä¶ that we might start to behave in ways that we think will keep us ‚Äòsafe‚Äô vs. ways that are actually most effective for getting what we need.

There is absolutely NOTHING wrong with the desire to feel seen, heard, and understood‚Ä¶ however, there are certainly some methods that are more conducive to getting this need met than others. 

If effective and appropriate communication and conflict resolution were not taught nor role modeled during your upbringing, it can feel really foreign to try to do so now. 

However, just because it takes a lot of work and practice, doesn‚Äôt mean it isn‚Äôt achievable. 

Start by increasing self-awareness around your triggers, your maladaptive responses, and the methods that are most effective for helping you to regulate when feeling upset‚Ä¶ these three areas of self-awareness are a great place to start when learning how to respond vs. react. ‚ô•Ô∏è

Conflict and war can often bring with it prejudice and discrimination, whether against people or a country. 

When talking to your children, avoid labels like ‚Äúbad people‚Äù or ‚Äúevil‚Äù and instead use it as an opportunity to encourage compassion, such as for the children and families who have lost their homes, have no water or electricity.

Even when a conflict is happening in a distant country, it can fuel discrimination on our doorstep. Get curious and ask your children whether they experiencing or contributing to bullying. If they have called others names or joined in with bullying explore what is going on that led them to want to hurt someone this way. Hold back from punishing or losing it on your child, model what compassion and curiosity look like instead of 

Remind your child that everyone deserves to be safe at school and in society. We should each do our part to spread kindness and support each other, this is particularly important at times when the world is full of pain.

Check if your child would like to participate in taking positive action. Perhaps they could participate in a local fundraiser, join a petition or add some of their pocket money towards the Red Cross or other organisation helping on the ground. 

‚ô•Ô∏èThe sense of doing something, no matter how small, can often bring great comfort.
‚≠êÔ∏èThis is my small action that I hope will offer something useful. 

Sending love to all, particularly those near and far who are affected.

Many people fail to make progress because they are unable to master their drives and instincts, specifically our need for food. Our nutrition is tied to with our emotional life and is ultimately the battle ground in which we strengthen the will. The person who is unable to deny themselves soon finds it difficult to endure other forms of discomfort such as conflict and stress.

However, the world hears this with infected ears. The world teaches that the goal is to be slim and in have a pleasing appearance. As with most things, the world takes something that is good and distorts it with subtle lies. A person does not necessarily have temperance if they are thin or have a six pack. Likewise, a person is not necessarily a glutton if they are overweight. The reason is that the overall health of a person involves many factors, such as hormones and DNA, and while there is a connection between health and virtue, it is not necessarily as direct as some would believe.

That being said, I think we are entering a new era in asceticism where we can take the genuine insights from the tradition and integrate them with contemporary understanding of nutrition.

The main distinction we need to make when understanding the history of Christian fasting and asceticism is between a caloric deficit and a simple diet‚Ä¶

‚ÄúLord, we confess that at times, we feel overwhelmed by the storm. But Today, we lift our eyes to you ‚Äî the Maker of heaven and earth. And we ask for a miracle‚Ä¶ let your peace fill Israel and Gaza. 
God, let violence cease in the region. Let there be no more bloodshed. We know your heart breaks for those killed and those left behind ‚Äî for the orphaned child, the injured elderly, those abducted and families desperate for safety. Lord, speak into this crisis. 
We pray for those who have lost loved ones. Let your peace and love wash over them. Please protect and provide for those who have been abducted and bring them home safely. Let them be reunited with their loved ones ‚Äî let them feel the comfort of their embrace.
God, we pray that you open doors that allow food, essentials and medical supplies to reach those in need. May first responders be able to rescue the injured, comfort the grieving and help rebuild many lives. 
God, we pray for your peace and reconciliation to overcome conflict. We ask that you give wisdom and discernment to our global leaders and those in positions of power who have the ability to impact the course of this war. Help us to be bold advocates and agents of peace in our own communities.
We pray for people scattered around the globe whose friends and family members have been caught in the crisis. We know you are with them. Help us to express your love to those affected. 
Lord, we raise Israel and Gaza to you, and pray for those suffering. We ask that you provide peace in this crisis, and protection and comfort for all those who have been impacted. 
We lift our prayer to you, Lord, hear us. ‚Äúüôèüèº‚ú®
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
#peace #prayer #prayerworks #prayforpeace #preghiera #dove #peaceisthegoal #peaceful #peaceandlove #peaceout #peaceonearth #hope #love

What is the responsibility of a newsroom in a time like this? This is the question we asked ourselves as the horrors of war streamed onto our televisions and social media feeds. 

We know that many expect us to pick a position; just as they do for every other entity in the 21st-century globalised world ‚Äì from football clubs to fast food chains.

But nuance drowns in a sea of noise. 

The Mail & Guardian‚Äôs stance on the ‚ÄúPalestinian question‚Äù has always been unequivocal. As a publication born during the dying grip of apartheid, we support the Palestinian right to autonomy and denounce the creeping occupation of its land.

That does not mean we support the violence wrought by the firing of thousands of rockets by Hamas into Israel, or that country‚Äôs retaliatory bombing of Gaza. We condemn all violence inflicted on civilians in any conflict around the globe. 

We are acutely cautious, however, of playing into an asinine, binary view of the world.

Read the rest of the M&G Editorial on mg.co.za

We're thrilled that our #EU4Dialogue project inspires women, like Lali Omadze, a dynamic and determined resident of Pkhvenisi village, located near the Administrative Boundary Line with South Ossetia/Tskhinvali region.

EU4Dialogue empowers rural women in Shida Kartli and other conflict-affected regions, equipping them with knowledge and skills, offering diverse training opportunities, and helping them thrive as entrepreneurs. Many of these initiatives are in collaboration with local civil society organizations, such as the "Peace Research Centre Tbilisi."

Through EU4Dialogue, @euingeorgia and UNDP champion local civic endeavours that support rural women and youth, and benefit hundreds of people across Georgia.

‚ö†Ô∏è gr–∞—Ähic —Å–ænt–µnt ‚ö†Ô∏è Israeli army announced its readiness for war. The armed wing of –Ωa#–º#as announced the launch of Operation Al-Aqsa Flood against Israel. In the first 20 minutes of the operation, 5,000 rockets were fired from the Gaza Strip.

As part of the humanitarian efforts undertaken by the UAE to provide urgent assistance to the Palestinian people, Dubai and the rest of the emirates (soon) have launched a campaign to provide relief aid to the Palestinian people impacted by the war in the Gaza Strip, under the theme ‚ÄòTarahum - for Gaza‚Äô.

The campaign will be inaugurated on Sunday, 15th October 2023, in Abu Dhabi, under the supervision of the Emirates Red Crescent at the Abu Dhabi Ports Hall in Mina Zayed from 9 am - 4 pm, and will be organized across the rest of the Emirates at a later date.
this campaign aims to mitigate the severity of the humanitarian conditions, and alleviate the suffering of the most vulnerable groups, especially children, who constitute nearly half of the population of the Gaza Strip. More than one million children are affected by the current conflict, and the campaign will work towards providing children and mothers with basic needs, in addition to health supplies and general hygiene materials. 
The aid will be sent through the United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA) for Palestine Refugees in the Near East.

To sit around the table with food to eat, water to drink, with those you love safe by your side is a gift. I am so grateful for dinners with some of mine. My prayers are with everyone missing a loved one right now. It is so easy to feel powerless in times like these but our compassion is our power. 

We all have a light inside of us and the power to re-ignite hope for someone who is hurting right now.

There are so many innocent people suffering around the world, their lives destroyed or disrupted by foreign invasions, conflict, natural disasters, and senseless hatred and violence.

May we keep in our minds that innocent people are not their governments as we keep praying for the suffering to end. 

Keep shining your light out onto your corner of our world & tell those you love just how much they mean to you. ‚ù§Ô∏è #strongertogether

"Today, Iran conveyed a message to Israel through the United Nations, according to which if the IDF operation in Gaza continues, it will be forced to intervene, according to a diplomatic source privy to the details according to Walla news.

An Iranian response - whether directly, whether through the militias in Syria and Iraq or whether by providing backing for ƒ§*z…ì*ll*h's entry into the fighting, will turn the current crisis in Gaza into a regional war.

However, he emphasized that Iran has red lines and will be forced to respond if the IDF's operation in Gaza continues. The UN envoy delivered the words to the head of the National Assembly.

The Iranian Foreign Minister said today in a briefing for reporters in Beirut after his meeting with ƒ§*z…ì*ll*h Secretary General Hassan Nasrallah that Israel must stop its war crimes immediately because it may be too late in a few hours.

The Iranian Foreign Minister said that Hezbollah had prepared several escalation scenarios that would cause an earthquake in Israel.

AN UNLIKELY PAIR‚Ä¶

Falcon is a kid. He thinks he hears the call of magic, and the voice of one of the Great Spirits seems to whisper in his ears. He‚Äôs come to the urban jungle of Seattle to seek his calling.

That 'the powers that be' consider that ability a danger because being so deeply empathic would keep us from engaging in war, from hurting one another, and being tools in this cruel chess game they seem to play. Feeling empathy for those who we might not know could allow us to move through the world with compassion and create a better, more loving world."

Thai Muslims in Pattani pray for Palestinians
.
Hundreds of Thai Muslims attended Friday prayers at Pattani Central Mosque in Muang district of Pattani province on Friday (October 13).
.
The prayers on Friday included ‚ÄúQunut Nazilah‚Äù, a supplication for Allah's protection from harm at times of calamity, aimed at sending moral support to Palestinians who are undergoing enormous suffering because of the war between the Hamas militant group and the Israeli army in the Gaza Strip since last week.
.
The mosque‚Äôs Imam, who led the prayers, told those present that they were lucky to be born in Pattani, the land with no war, and urged them to pray for other Muslim brothers and sisters for their safety and peace in the conflict-ridden region.
.

The 2023 Global Hunger Index shows that far too many people go to bed hungry. Hunger remains serious or alarming in 43 countries, while progress in many countries has stagnated or even reversed due to conflict, climate change and the global pandemic.

But there are positives to take from the #GHI23. 

Despite the challenges facing the world, some countries‚Äîincluding Bangladesh, Chad, Djibouti, Lao PDR, Mozambique, Nepal, and Timor-Leste‚Äîhave shown remarkable progress since 2015. Bangladesh has gone from a GHI score of 26.2 in 2015, to 19.0 this year. 

Concern Worldwide has been working in Bangladesh for 51 years, supporting people like Hosenare through programmes like Collective Responsibility, Action and Accountability for Improved Nutrition (CRAAIN).

Hosenare received training on nutrition, climate-smart agriculture techniques, water use, and sanitation and was provided with a goat and four ducks. Her participation helped her build up her small farm while enabling her family to withstand climate shocks such as typhoons and flooding. 

She said: ‚ÄúI feel empowered and have a dream of increasing my small farm. I received just one goat, and now I have three. I dream of having 10 or more to help me earn more and preserve my farm.‚Äù

Look, I really don‚Äôt care what side of the current conflict you take. In fact, I think being on either side exclusively is deeply cringe. 

That said, can we stop it with the boomer evangelicalism about the who the chosen people are? The OT makes it extremely clear that to be a part of the nation but unfaithful is no better than being a pagan. Also, people from an non ethnic background are joined to God‚Äôs people (Phineas, Rahab, Ruth, etc.) through faithfulness and obedience. 

The NT is equally clear that those who reject Christ reject God. Every Gospel is unequivocal about this, and we see it play out in Acts of the Apostles. St. Paul gives the theological reasoning and explanation of what the Law was for, and who Israel was supposed to be, and who the current children of St. Abraham are. 

God desires faithfulness, not geopolitical standing. The point isn‚Äôt to castigate the Israelites, it‚Äôs to examine ourselves and see if we also are rejecting God by failing to keep His commandments.

Supporting Palestine is not about taking sides; it is about standing on the side of justice, equality, and human dignity.
